div.head: THE DEDICATION.
div.p: I Have often (during this Plays being in the Press) been importun'd for a Preface; which you, I suppose, would have speak something in Vindication of the Comedy: Now to please you, Mr. Bentley, I will as briefly as I can speak my mind upon that occasion, which you may be pleas'd to accept of, both as a Dedication to your self, and next as a Preface to the Book.

And I am not a little proud, that it has happened into my thoughts to be the first who in these latter years, has made an Epistle Dedicatory to his Stationer: It is a Complement as reasonable as it is Just. For, Mr. Bentley, you pay honestly for the Copy; and an Epistle to you is a sort of an Acquittance, and may be probably welcome; when to a Person of higher Rank and Order, it looks like an Obligation for Praises, which he knows he does not deserve, and therefore is very unwilling to part with ready Money for.

As to the Vindication of this Comedy, between
Friends and Acquaintance, I believe it is possible, that as much may be said in it's behalf, as heretofore has been for a great many others: But of all the Apish qualities about me, I have not that of being fond of my own Issue; nay, I must confess my self a very unnatural Parent, for when it is once brought into the World, E'en let the Brat shift for it self, I say.
The Objections made against the merit of this poor Play, I must confess, are very grievous.

First, Says a Lady, that shall be nameless, because the World may think civilly of her; Fogh! oh Sherru! 'tis so filthy, so bawdy, no modest Woman ought to be seen at it: Let me dye, it has made me sick: When the World lies, Mr. Bentley, if that very Lady has not easily digested a much ranker morsel in a little Ale-house towards Paddington, and never made a Face at it: But your true Jilt is a Creature that can extract Bawdy out of the chastest sence, as easily as a Spider can Poison out of a Rose: They know true Bawdy, let it be never so much conceal'd, as perfectly as Falstaff did the true Prince by instinct: They will separate the true Metal from the Allay let us temper it as well as we can; some Women are the Touch-stones of filthiness. Though I have heard a Lady (that has more modesty than any of those the Criticks,
and I am sure more wit) say, She wonder'd at the impudence of any of her Sex, that would pretend to understand the thing call'd Bawdy. So, Mr. Bentley, for ought I perceive, my Play may be innocent yet, and the Lady mistaken in pretending to the knowledge of a Mystery above he●; though, to speak honestly, she has had besides her Wit a liberal Education; and 〈◊〉 we may credit the World has not buried her Talent neither.

This is, Mr. Bentley, all I can say in behalf of my Play: Wherefore I throw it into Your Arms, make the best of it you can; praise, it to your Customers: Sell ten thousand of them if possible, and then you will compleat the wishes of

closer.signed: Your Friend and Servant, THO. OTWAY.

div.head: PROLOGUE, by the Lord Falkland
div.l: FOrsaken Dames with less concern reflect
On their inconstant Hero's cold neglects,
Than we (provok'd by this Vngrateful Age,)
Bear the hard Fate of our abandon'd Stage;
With grief we see you ravisht from our Arms,
And Curse the Feeble Vertue of our Charms:
Curse your false hearts, for none so false as they,
And curse the Eyes that stole those hearts away.
Remember Faithless Friends there was a time,
(But oh the sad remembrance of our Prime!)
When to our Arms with eager Ioys ye flew,
And we believ'd your treach'rous Hearts as true
As e're was Nymph of ours to one of you:
But a more pow'rful * * Pope 〈◊〉 Saint enjoys ye now;
Fraught with sweet sins and absolutions too:
To her are all your pious Vows addrest,
She's both your Loves, and your Religion's Test,
The fairest Prelate of her time and best.
We own her more deserving far then we,
A just excuse for your inconstancy.
Yet 'twas unkindly done to leave us so:
First to betray with Love, and then undo,
A horrid Crime y'are all addicted to.
Too soon, alas, your Appetites are cloy'd,
And Phillis rules no more, when once enjoy'd:
But all rash Oaths of Love and constancy,
With the too short forgotten Pleasures dye,
Whilst she, poor Soul, rob'd of her dearest ease,
Still drudges on, with vain desire to please;
And restless follows you from place to place,
For Tributes due to her Autumnal Face:
Deserted thus by such ungrateful men,
How can we hope you'l e're return agen?
Here's no new Charm to tempt ye as before,
Wit now's our only Treasure left in store,
And that's a Coyn will pass with you no more▪
You who such dreadful Bullies would appear,
(True Bullyes! quiet when there's danger near)
Shew your great Souls in damning Poets here.

div.head: THE Souldiers Fortune.
ACT. I. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: APox o' Fortune! Thou art always teizing me about Fortune: Thou risest in a Morning with ill luck in thy Mouth; Nay, never eatest a Dinner, but thou sighest two hours after it, with thinking where to get the next. Fortune be damn'd, since the worlds so wide.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: As wide as it is; 'tis so throng'd, and cramm'd with Knaves and Fools, that an honest man can hardly get a living in it.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Do, rail, Courtine, do, it may get thee employment.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: At you I ought to rail▪ 'twas your fault we left our Employments abroad to come home, and be Loyal, and now we as Loyally starve for it.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Did not thy Ancestors do it before thee, man? I tell thee, Loyalty and Starving are all one: The old Cavaliers got such a trick of it in the Kings Exile, that their posterity could never thrive since.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: 'Tis a fine Equipage I am like to be reduc'd to: I shall be e're long as greasy as an Alsatia Bully; this a flopping Hat, pin'd up on one side, with a sandy weather-beaten Perruque, dirty Linned, and to compleat the Figure, a long scandalous Iron Sword jarring at my Heels, like a—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Snarling thou meanest like it's Master.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: My Companion's the worthy Knight of the most Noble Order of the Post: Your Peripatetrick Philosophers of the Temple walks, Rogues in Rags, and yet not honest: Villains that undervalue Damnation, will forswear themselves for a Dinner, and hang their Fathers For half a Crown.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I am asham'd to hear a Souldier talk of starving.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Why, what shall I do? I can't steal!—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Though thou canst not steal, thou hast other vices enough for any Industrious young fellow to live comfortably upon.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: What wouldst thou have me turn Rascal, and run cheating up and down the Town for a livelihood? I would no more keep a Blockhead company, and endure his Nauseous non-sense in hopes to get him, then I would be a druge to an old Woman, with Rheumatick Eyes, hollow Teeth, and stinking breath for a pensioa: Of all Rogues I would not be a Foolmonger.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: How well this niceness becomes thee! I'd fain see thee ee'n turn Parson in a pet, o'purpose to rail at all those vices which I know thou naturally art fond of: Why surely an Old Ladies pension need not be so despicable in the eyes of a disbanded Officer, as times go Friend.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: I am glad, Beaugard you think so.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why thou shalt think so too man; be rul'd by me, and I'll bring thee into good company, Families, Courtine, Families, and such Families, where formality's a scandel and pleasure is the bus'ness, where the Women are all Wanton, and the Men all Witty, you Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: What, some of your Worships Wapping acquaintance that you made last time you came over for recruits, and Spirited away your Landladies Daughter, a Volunteering with you into France.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I'll bring thee, 〈◊〉, where Cuckoldom● in credit, and lewdness laudable, where thou shalt wallow in pleasures and preferments, rival all day, and every Night lye in the Armes of melting beauty, sweet as Roses, and as Springs refreshing.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: 〈…〉 thou wouldest tell me where new Levies are to be rais'd; a Pox of Whoever when a man has not Money to mak'e●● Comfortable.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: That shall shower upon us in abundance, and for instance, know to thy everlasting amazement all this dropt out of the Clouds so day.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Hah! Gold by this light!—

sp.speaker: Fourb
sp.p: Out of the Clouds!—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Ay hold! does it not smell of the sweet hand than 〈◊〉, smell— smell you dog—

div.stage: [Fourbin smells to the handful of gold, and gathers up some pieces in his Mouth.

sp.speaker: Four.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, of Heavenly sweetness: and 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Dear, 〈◊〉 if thou hast▪ any good Nature 〈◊〉 thee; if thou wouldst not have me hang my self before my time, tell me where the Devil 〈◊〉 that helpt thee to this, that I may go make a bargain with him presently: Speak, speak, or I am a lost Man.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p:
Why thou must know this Devil which I have given my
Soul too already, and must, I suppose have my Body very speedily lives I know not where, and may for ought I know be a real Devil; but if it be 'tis the best natur'd Devil under Beelzebubs dominion that I'll swear too.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: But how came the gold then?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: To deal freely with my Friend, I am lately happen'd into the acqaintance of a very Reverend pimp, as fine a discreet sober gray bearded old Gentleman as one would wish; as good a natur'd publick spirited Person as the Nation holds; one that is never so happy as when he is bringing good people together, and promoting civil understanding betwixt the sexes: Nay, rather then want employment, he will go from one end of the Town to t'other to procure my Lords little Dog to be civil to my Ladies little languishing Bitch.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: A very worthy Member of the Common-Wealth!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: This noble Person one day— but Fourbin can give you a more particular account of the matter; sweet Sir, if you please tell us the story of the first encounter betwixt you and Sir Iolly Iumble, you must know that's his Title.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Sir, it shall be done— walking one day upon the Piazza about three of the Clock i'th' after Noon, to get me a Stomach to my dinner, I chance to encounter a Person of goodly presence, and worthy appearance, his Beard and Hair white, grave and comely, his countenance ruddy Plump smooth and cheerful; who perceiving me also equipt as I am with a meen and Air which might well inform him, I was a Person of no inconsiderable quality, came very respectfully up to me, and, after the usual ceremonies between Persons of parts and breeding had past, very humbly enquired of me what is it a Clock— I presently understand by the question, that he was a man of parts and business, told him, I did presume it was at most but nicely turn'd of three—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Very Court-like, civil, quaint, and new I think.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: The freedom of comerce increasing after some little inconsiderable questions pour po●●er●le temps and so he was pleased to offer me the courtesle of a glass of Wine: I told him I very seldom drank, but if he so pleas'd, I would do my self the honour to present him with a dish of meat at an eating House hard by, where I had an interest.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Very well: I think this Squire of thine, Beauggard, is as accomplisht a Person as any of the employment I ever saw.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Let the Rogue go on.

sp.speaker: Four.
sp.p:
In short we agreed and went together as soon as we entred the Room▪ I am your most humble Servant, Sir, says he— I am the meanest of your Vassals, Sir, said I— I am very happy in lighting into the acqaintance of so worthy a Gentleman as you appear to be, Sir, sayd he again— worthy, Sir Iolly, then came I upon him again o'
tother side (for you must know by that time I had gropt out his Title) I kiss your hands from the bottom of my heart, which I shall be always ready to lay at your Feet.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Well, Fourbin, and what reply'd the Knight then?

sp.speaker: Four.
sp.p: Nothing, he had nothing to say, his sense was transported with admiration of my parts, so we sat down, and after some pause, he desired to know by what title he was to distinguish the person that had so highly honoured him—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: That is as much as to say▪ Sir, whose Rascal you were.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Sir, you may make as hold with your poor Slave as you please— I told him those that knew me well were pleased to call me the Chevalier Fourbin, that I was a Cadel of the Ancient Family of the Fourbinois and that I had had the honour of serving the great Monarch of France in his Wars in Flanders, where I contracted great Familiarity, and Intimacy with a gallant Officer of the English, Troops in that service one Captain Beaugard.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you did me too much honour, what a true bred Rogue's this!—

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Well but the Money, Fourbin, the Money.

sp.speaker: Four.
sp.p: Beaugard, 〈◊〉 Beaugard, says he ●— ay it must be so,— a black man, is he not?— 〈◊〉, says I, blackish— a dark brown— full Fac't— yes,— a sly subtle observing eye?— the same— a strong built well made man?— right— a devellish fellow for a Wench, a devilish fellow for a Wench, I warrant him; a thundring Rogue upon occasion, Beaugard! a Thundering fellow for a Wench, I must be acquained with him.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: But to the money, the money man, that's the thing I would be acquainted withall.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: This civil Gentleman of the Chevaliers acquaintance comes yesterday morning to my Lodging, and seeing my Picture in Minature upon the Toylet, told me with the greatest extasie in the World, that was the thing he came to me about: He told me there was a Lady of his acquaintance had some favourable thoughts of me and I gad, says he, she's a hummer, such a bona Roba ah-h-h. So without more ado begs me to lend it him till dinner (for we concluded to eat together) so away he scuttled with as great joy as if he had found the Philosophers stone.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: At Lockets we met again: where after a thousand grimaces to shew how much he was pleas'd, instead of my Picture, presents me with the contents aforesaid; and told me the Lady desir'd me to accept of 'em for the Picture which she was much transported withall, as well as with the Original.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Hah!—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p:
Now, whereabouts this taking quality lies in me, the Devil
take me Ned if I know: But the Fates Ned, the Fates!

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: A Curse on the Fates! Of all Strumpets Fortunes the basest, 'twas Fortune made me a Souldier, a Rogue in Red, the grievance of the Nation, Fortune made the peace just when we were upon the brink of a War; then Fortune disbanded us, and lost us two Months pay: Fortune gave us Debentures instead of ready Money, and by very good Fortune I sold mine, and lost heartily by it, in hopes the grinding ill natur'd dog that bought it will never get a shilling for't—

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Leave off thy railing for shame, it looks like a Cur that barks for want of bones; come times may mend, and an honest Souldier be in fashion again—

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: These greasie fat unwieldy wheeting Rogues that live at home and brood over their bags, when a fit of fear's upon 'em then if one of us pass but by, all the Family is ready at the door to cry, Heaven's bless you, Sir, the Laird go along with you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Ah good men, what pity 'tis such proper Gentlemen should ever be out of Employment.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: But when the bus'ness is over, then every Parish Bawd that goes but to a Conventicle twice a Week, and pays but scot and lot to the Parish, shall roar out fogh, ye Lowsy Red-coat rake hells▪ hout ye Caterpillars, ye Locusts of the Nation, you are the Dogs that would enslave us all, plunder our Shops, and ravish our Daughters, ye Scoundrels.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I must confess ravishing ought to be regulated, it would destroy commerce, and many a good Sober Matron about this Town might loose the selling of her Daughters Maiden-Head, which were a great grieyance to the people, and a particular Branch of property lost, Fourbin.

sp.speaker: Four.
sp.p: Your Worships pleasure.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Run like a Rogue as you are, and try to find Sir Iolly, and desire him to meet me at the blew Posts in the Hay-market about 12, we'll Dine together; I must inquire farther into yesterdays adventure, in the mean time, Ned, here's half the prize to be doing withall, old friends must preserve Correspondence, we have shar'd good Fortune together and had shall never part us.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Well, thou wilt certainly die in a Ditch for this, hast thou no more grace then, to be a true Friend, nay, to part with thy money to thy Friend; I grant you a Gentleman may swear and lye for his Friend, pimp for his Friend, hang for his Friend, and so forth: but to part with ready money is the devil.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Stand aside either I am mistaken, or yonder's Sir Iolly coming; now Courtine, will I shew thee the Flower of Knighthood▪ Ah, Sir Iolly.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: My Hero! my darling! my Ganimede! how dost thou? Strong! wanton! lusty! rampant! hah, ah, ah! She's thine Boy▪ odd she's thine, plump, soft, smooth, wanton! hah, ah, ah! Ah Rogue, ah Rogue! here's shouldiers, here's shape! there's a Foot and Leg, here's a Leg, here's a Leg— Quaa-a-a-a.

div.stage: [Squeaks like a Cat, and tickles Beaugards Legs.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: What an old Goat's this.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Child, Child, Child, who's that? A friend of thine! a friend o'thine? A pretty fellow, odd a very prety fellow, and a strong dog I'll warrant him, how dost do dear heart? prithee let me kiss thee, I'll swear and vow I will kiss thee, ha, ha, he, he, he, he, a Toad, A Toad, ah Toa-a-a-ad—

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Sir, I am your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But the Lady, Sir Iolly, the Lady, how does the Lady, what says the Lady, Sir Iolly?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: What says the Lady! why she says— she says— odd she has a delicate Lip, such a Lip, so red, so hard, so plump, so blub▪ I fancy I am eating Cherries every time I think on't— and for her Neck and Breasts and her— odds life; I'll say no more, not a word more, but I know, I know—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I am sorry for that with all my Heart; do you know, say you, Sir, and would you put off your mubled orts, your offall upon me—

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Hush, hush, hush! have a care, as I live and breathe, not I; alack and well a day I am a poor old fellow decay'd and done: Alls gone with me Gentlemen, but my good Nature, odd I love to know how matters go, though now and then to see a pretty Wench, and a young Fellow Towze and Rowze and Frouze and Mowze; odd I love a young fellow dearly, faith dearly—

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: This is the most extraordinary rogue, I ever met withall.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But Sir Iolly, in the first place, you must know, I have sworn never to marry.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: I would not have thee man, I am a Bachelour my self, and been a whore Master all my life, besides she's married already man, her Husband's an old greasie, untoward, ill natur'd, slovenly, Tobacco taking Cuckold, but plaguy ●ealous.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Already a Cuckold, Sir Iolly.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: No that shall be my Boy, thou shalt make him one, and I'll pimp for thee dear heart, and shan't I hold the door, shan't I peep hah, shan't I you devil, you little dog shan't I?—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: What is it, I'd not grant to oblige my Patron.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p:
And then dost hear, I have a lodging for thee in my own house; dost hear old Soul, in my own house: She lives the very next
door man, there's but a Wall to part her Chamber and thine, and then for a peep hole, odds fish I have a peep hole for thee; sbud I'll shew thee, I'll shew thee—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But when, Sir Iolly, I am in haste, impatient.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Why this very night man; poor Rogue's in haste, poor Rogue; but hear you—

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: The matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Shan't we dine together?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: The Maw begins to empty, get you before and bespeak Dinner at the blew posts; while I stay behind and gather up a dish of Whores for a desert.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Be sure that they be lew'd drunken stripping Whores, Sir Iolly, that won't be affectedly squeamish and troublesome.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: I love a well disciplin'd Whore, that shews all the tricks of her profession with a wink; like an old Souldier that understands all his exercise by beat of Drum.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: A Thief, sayest thou so! I must be better acquainted with that fellow; he has a notable Nose; a hard brawny Carle— true and trusty, and mettle I'll warrant him.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Well, Sir Iolly, you'l not fail us?—

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Fail ye! am I a Knight? hark ye Boys. I'l muster this evening, such a Regiment of Rampant. Roaring, Roysterous Whores, that shall make more noise than if all the Cats in the Hay market were in Conjunction: Whores ye Rogues, that shall swear with you, drink with you, talk Bawdy with you, fight with you, scratch with you, lye with you, and go to the Devil with you, shan't we be very merry, hah!—

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: As merry as Wine, Women and Wickedness can make us.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Odd that's well said again, very well said, as merry as Wine, Women and wickedness can make us: I love a fellow that is very wicked dearly; methinks there's a spirit in him, there's a sort of a tantara, rara, tantara, ra ra, ah ah h h well, and won't ye, when the Women come, won't ye, and shall I not see a little sport amongst you; well get ye gone; ah Rogues, ah Rogues, da da, I'll be with you, da da—

sp.speaker: 1 Bul.
sp.p: In the name of Satan what Whores are those in their Copper 〈◊〉, yonder?

sp.speaker: 1 Who.
sp.p: Well I'll swear, Madam, 'tis the finest Evening: I love thee, Mall, mightily.

sp.speaker: 2 Bul.
sp.p: Let's huzza the Bulkers.

sp.speaker: 2. Whor.
sp.p: Really, and so do I, because there's alwaies good company, aud one meets with such Civilitys from every body.

sp.speaker: 3. Bul.
sp.p: Damn'd Whores, hout ye filthies.

sp.speaker: 3. Whor.
sp.p: Ay, and then I love extreamly to shew my self here, when I am very fine, to vex those poor Devils that call themselves Vertues, and are very scandalous and Crapish, I'll swear; O Crimine, who's yonder! Sir Iolly Iumble, I vow.

sp.speaker: 1 Bul.
sp.p: Fogh! Let's leave the nasty Sowes to Fools, and Diseases.

sp.speaker: 1 Wher▪
sp.p: Oh Papa, Papa! where have you been these two days, Papa?

sp.speaker: 2 Who.
sp.p: You are a precious Father indeed, to take no more care of your Children: We might be dead for all you, you naughty Dady, you.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Dead, my poor Fubses! odd I had rather all the Relations I have were dead, a dad I had: Get you gone you little Devils Bubbies; oh Law there's Bubbies! odd I'll bite 'em, odd I will.

sp.speaker: 1 Whor.
sp.p: Nay, fye, Papa; I swear you'l make me angry, except you carry us, and treat us to Night, you have promis'd me a treat this Week, wont you Papa.

sp.speaker: 2 Whor.
sp.p: Ay, wont you Dad.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Odds so, odds so, well remember'd! get you got, don't stay talking; get you gone, yonder's, a great Lord, the Lord Beaugard, and his Couzin the Baron, the Count, the Marquis, the Lord knows what, Monsieur Courtine newly come to Town, odds so.

sp.speaker: 3 Whor.
sp.p: Oh Law, where Dady where? Oh dear, a Lord.

sp.speaker: I Whor.
sp.p: Well, you are the Purest Papa; but when be dey mun, Papa—

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: I won't tell you, you Jipsies, So I wont— except you tickle me— 'sbud they are brave fellows all Tall, and not a bit small, odd one of 'em has a devillish deal of Monie.

sp.speaker: 1 Whor.
sp.p: Oh dear, but which is he, Papa.

sp.speaker: 2. Whor.
sp.p: Shan't I be in Love with him, Dady.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: What no body tickle me! no body tickle me?— not yet, tickle me a little Mally— tickle me a little Ienny— do He he he he he he— (They tickle him. No more, oh dear, oh dear! poor Rogues, so so, no more, nay, if you do, if you do, odd I'l I'l I'l—

sp.speaker: 3 Why
sp.p: What, what will you do trow?—

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Come along with me, come along with me, sneak after me at a distance, that no bodie take notice, Swinging fellows Mally— Swinging fellows Ienny, a Devillish deal of Monie, get you afore me then, you little d●ppappers, ye Wasps, ye wagtails, get youg on, I say, swinging fellows—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Dye a Maid, Sylvia! sie for shame! what a scandalous resolution's that; five thousand Pounds to your Portion and leave it all to Hospitals, for the innocent recreation hereafter of leading Apes in Hell, fie for shame!

sp.speaker: Sylvia.
sp.p: Indeed such another charming Animal as your Consort, Sir David, might do much with me; 'tis an unspeakable blessing to lye all night by a Horse-load of diseases; a beastly, unsayory, old, groaning, grunting, wheazing Wretch, that smells of the Grave he's going to already, from such a curse and Hair-Cloath next my skin good Heaven deliver me!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Thou mistakest the use of a Husband, Silvia. They are not meant for Bedfellows, heretofore indeed 'twas a fulsome fashion, to ly o'nights with a Husband; but the worlds improv'd and Customs altered.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Pray instruct then what the use of a Husband is.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Instead of a Gentleman-Usher for Ceremonies sake to be in waiting on set days, and particular occasions; but the Friend Cozen is the Jewel unvaluable.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: But, Sir David, Madam will be difficult to be so Govern'd; I am mistaken, if his Nature is not too Jealous to be blinded.

sp.speaker: Lady Du.
sp.p: So much the better, of all, the jealous Fool is easiest to be deceiv'd: For observe, where there's jealousie there's always fondness; which if a Woman, as she ought to do, will make the right use of the Husband's fears shall not so awake him on one side as his dotage shall blind him on the other.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Is your Piece of mortality such a doteing Doodle, is he so very fond of you.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: No, but he has the vanity to think that I am very fond of him, and if he be jealous, 'tis not so much for fear I do abuse, as that in time I may, and therefore imposes this consinement on me though he has other divertisments that take him off from my injoyment; which make him so loathsome no Woman but must hate him.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: His private divertisements I am a stranger to.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Then for his Person 'tis incomparably odious, he has such-a breath, one kiss of him were enough to cure the fits of the Mother, 'tis worse then Asa foetida.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Oh hideous!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Every thing that's nasty he affects, clean Linnen he says is unwholesome, and to make him more charming he's continually eating of Garlike and chewing Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Fogh! this is love! this is the blessing of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Lady Du.
sp.p: Rail not so unreasonably against love, Silvia; As I have dealt freely and acknowledged to thee the passion I have for Beaugard; so methinks, Silvia need not conceal her good thoughts of her Friend; do not I know Courtine sticks in your stomach?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: If he does, I'll assure you he shall never get to my heart, but can you have the Conscience to love another man now you are married? what do you think will become of you.?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I tell thee, Sylvia, I never was married to that Engine we have been talking of, my parents indeed made me say something to him after a Priest once, but my heart went not along with my tongue, I minded not what it was for my thoughts, Sylvia, for these seven years have been much better imploy'd— Beaugard! Ah curse on the day that first sent him into France!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Why so I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Had he stay'd here, I had not been sacrific'd to the Arms of this monument of Man, for the bed of death could not be more cold, then his has been, he would have delivered me from the Monster, for even then I loved him, and was apt to think my kindness not neglected.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: I find indeed your Ladyship had good thoughts of him.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Surely 'tis impossible to think too well of him, for he has wit enough to call his good nature in question, and yet good nature enough to make his wit be suspected.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: But how do you hope ever to get sight of him, Sir David's watchfulness is invincible. I dare swear he wou'd smell out a Rival if he were in the house only by natural instinct, as some that always sweat when a Cat's in the Room, then again, Beaugard's a Souldiers and that's a thing the old Gentleman you know loves dearly.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: There lies the greatest comfort of my uneasie life he is one of those Fools forsooth, that are led by the Nose by Knaves to rail against the King and the Government, and is mightly fond of being thought of a party, I have had hopes this twelve month to have heard of his being in the Gate-House for Treason.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: But I find only your self the Prisoner all this while.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p:
At present indeed I am so, but Fortune I hope
will smile, wouldst thou but be my Friend, Sylvia.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: In any mischievous design withall my heart.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: The conclusion, Madam, may turn to your satisfaction, but you have no thoughts of Courtine.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Not I, I'll assure you Cozen.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: You don't think him well shap'd, streight and proportionable.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Considering he eats but once a Week, the man is well enough.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: And then wears his Cloaths you know filthily and like a horrid Sloven.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Filthily enough of all Conscience, with a thred bare Red-Coat, which his Taylor ●●ns him for to this day, over which a great broad greasie bury Belt, enough to turn any ones Stomach but a disbanded Souldier; a Perruquety'd up in a knot to excuse its want of combing, and then because he has been a Man a Armes, he must wear two Tussles of a Beard forsooth, to lodge a dunghill of snuff upon, to keep his Nose in good humour.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Nay, now I am suro that thou lovest him.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: So far from it, that I protest eternally against the whole sex.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: That time will best demonstrate, in the mean while to our business.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: As how, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady▪ D.
sp.p: To night must I see Beaugard, they are this minute at Dinner in the hay-market; now to make my evil genious, that haunts me every where, my thing called a Husband, himself to assist his poor Wife, at a dead lift, I think would not be unpleasant.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: But 'twill be impossible

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I am apt to be perswaded rather very easie, you know our good and friendly Neighbour, Sir Iolly.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Out on him beast, he's always talking silthily to a body, If he sits but at the table with one, he'll be making nasty figures in the Napkins.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: He and my sweet yoke fellow are the most intimate friends in the world, so that partly out of neighbourly kindness, as well as the great delight he takes to be medling in matters of this nature, with a great deal of pains and industry procured me Beaugards picture, and given him to understand how well a Friend of his in Petticoats, call'd my self, wishes him.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: But what's all this to the making the Husband instrumental, for I must confess of all creatures a Husbands the thing that's odious to me.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: That must be done this night: I'll in●stantly to my chamber take my bed in a pet and send for Sir David.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: But which way then must the Lover come?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Nay, I'll betray Beaugard to him, shew him the picture he sent me, and beg of him as he tenders his own honour, and my quiet, to take some course to secure me from the scandalous solicitations of that innocent Fellow.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: And so make him the property, the go-between, to bring the affair to an issue the more decently.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Right, Sylvia, 'tis the best office a Husband can do a Wife; I mean an old husband; bless us to be yok'd in Wedlock with a paralitick, coughing, decrepid Dotrell, to be a dry Nurse all ones life time to an old Child of sixty five, to lye by the Image of Death a whole night, a dull immoveable, that has no sense of life, but through it's pains, the Pidgeons as happy that's laid to a sick mans feet, when the world has given him over; for my part this shall henceforth be my prayer,

lg.l: Curst be the memory; nay, double curst,
Of her that wedded Age for interest first;
Though worn with years, with fruitless wishes full,
'Tis all day troublesome, and all night dull,
Who wed with Fools indeed lead happy lives,
Fools are the fittest finest things for Wives;
Yet old men Profit bring as Fools bring ease,
And both make Youth and Wit much better please.

div.head: ACT. II
div.stage: Enter Sir Jolly, Beaugard, Courtine, and Fourbin.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: SIR Iolly is the glory of the Age.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Nay now, Sir, you honour me too far.

sp.speaker: Beang.
sp.p: He's the delight of the young, and wonder of the old.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: I swear Gentlemen you make me blush.

sp.speaker: Gour.
sp.p: He deserves a Statue in Gold, at the charge of the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Out upon't, fye for shame: I protest I'll leave your comcompany if you talk so; but faith they were pure Whores, daintily dutiful Strumpets, ha! udds-bud, they'd— have stript for t'other Bottle.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Truly, Sir Iolly, you are a man of very extraordinary discipline, I never saw Whores under better command in my life.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioll.
sp.p: Pish, that's nothing man, nothing, I can send for forty better when I please, Doxies that will skip, strip, leap, trip, and do any thing in the world, any thing old Soul.

sp.speaker: Gour.
sp.p: Dear, dear Sir Iolly, where and when?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Odd as simply as I stand here her Father was a Knight.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Indeed Sir Iolly, a Knight say you?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Ay, but a little decay'd, I'll assure you she's a very good Gentlewoman born.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Ay, and a very good Gentlewoman bred too.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Ay, and so she is.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But Sir Iolly, how goes my business forward, when shall I have a view of the quarry I am to fly at?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Alas a day, not so hasty, soft and fair I beseech you, ah my little Son of thunder, if thou hadst her in thy arms now between a pair of sheets, and I under the Bed to see fair play Boy, gemini! what wou'd become of me? What wou'd become of me? there would be doings, oh Lawd, I under the bed!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Or behind the hangings, Sir Iolly, would not that do as well.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Ah no, under the bed against the world, and then it would be very dark, hah!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Dark to chuse.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: No, but a little light would do well, a small glimmering Lamp, just enough for me to steel a peep by; oh lamentable! oh lamentable, I won't speak a word more, there would be a trick! oh rare you friend, oh rare! odds so not a word more, odds so yonder comes the Monster that must be the Cuckold Elect, step step aside and observe him, if I shou'd be seen in your company, 'twoud spoil all.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: For my part I'll stand the meeting of him, one way to promote a good understanding with a Wife, is first to get acquainted with her Husband.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p:
Well of all blessings, a discreet Wife is the greatest that
can light upon a man of years: had I been married to any thing but and Angel now, what a Beast had I been by this time, well I am the happiest old Fool! 'tis an horrid Age that we live in, so that an honest man can keep nothing to himself; if you have a good estate, every covetous Rogue'ls longing for 〈◊〉 (truly I love a good estate dearly my self;) if you have a handsome Wife, every smoothfac'd Coxcomb will be combing and cocking at her, flesh-flies are not so troublesome to the shambles, as those sort of Insects are to the Boxes in the Play-house: But vertue is a great blessing, an unvaluable treasure, to tell me her self that a Villain had tempted her, and give me the very Picture, the inchantment that he sent to bewitch her, it strikes me dumb with admiration; here's the Villain in effigie. [Pulls out the Picture] Odd a very handsome fellow, a dangerous Rogue I'll warrant him, such fellows as these now should be fetter'd like unruly Colts, that they might not leap into other mens pastures; here's a Nose now, I cou'd find in my heart to cut it off, damn'd Dog, to dare to presume to make a Cuckold of a Knight! bless us what will this world come to! well poor Sir David down, down, on thy knees and thank thy stars for this deliverance.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: 'Sdeath what's that I see? Sure 'tis the very Picture which I sent by Sir Iolly, if so, by this light, I am damnably Jilted.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: But now if.—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Surely he does not see us yet.

sp.speaker: Four.
sp.p: See you, Sir, why he has but one eye, and we are on his blind side; I'll dumb found him.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Who the Divels this? Sir, Sir, Sir, who are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Ay, ay, 'tis the same, now a pox of all amorous adventures, 'sdeath I'll go beat the impertinent pimp that drew me into this fooling.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Sir, methinks you are very curious.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, perhaps I have an extraordinary reason to be so.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: And perhaps, Sir, I care not for you, nor your Reasons neither.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, if you are at leisure, I would beg the Honour to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: With me, Sir? What's your business with me?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I wou'd not willingly be troublesome; though it may be I am so at this time.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: It may be so too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But to be known to so worthy a Person as you are, would be so great an honour, so extraordinary a happiness, that I could not avoid taking this opportunity of tend'ring you my Service.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p:
Smooth Rogue, who the Divel is this fellow? (Aside.) But Sir, you were pleased to nominate business Sir, I desire with what
speed you can to know your business, Sir, that I may go about my business.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, if I might with good manners, I should be glad to inform my self, whose picture that is which you have in your hand, methinks it is very fine painting.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Picture, Friend, picture! Sir, 'tis the resemblance of a very impudent fellow, they call him Captain Beaugard forsooth, but he is in short a rakehell, a poor louzy beggarly disbanded devil, do you know him friend?—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I think I have heard of such a vagabond, the truth on't is he is a very impudent fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ay, a dam'd Rogue.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Oh a notorious scoundrel!

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: I expect to hear he's hang'd by next Sessions.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: The truth on't is, he has deserv'd it long ago; but did you ever see him, Sir David.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Sir— does he know me?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Because I fancy that Mignature is very like him, pray Sir, whence had it you?—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Had it, Friend? had it! whence had it I— bless us▪ what have I done now this the very Traytour himself, if he should be desperate now, and put his sword in my guts!— s●itting my nose will be as bad as that, I have but one eye left neither, and may be— oh but this is the Kings Court, odd tha's well remember'd he dares not but be civil here; I'll try to out-huff him, whence had it you?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, whence had it you? that's English in my Countrie, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Go, Sir, you are a Rascal.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Sir, I say, you are a Rascal, a very impudent Rascal, nay, I'll prove you to be a Rascal, if you go to that—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, I am a Gentleman and a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: So much the worse, Souldiers have been Cuckold makers from the beginning; Sir, I care not what you are; for ought I know you may be a— come Sir, did I never see you? answer me to that did I never see you? for ought I know you may be a Jesuit; there were more in the last armie beside you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Of your acquaintance, and be hang'd!

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Yes to my knowledge, there were several at Hounslow Heath disguised in dirtie Petticoats, and cry'd Brandy, I knew a Serjeant of foot that was familier with one of them all night in a Ditch, and fancy'd him a woman, but the Devil is powerful.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: In short, you worthy Villain of Worship, that picture is mine, and I must have it, or I shall take an opportunity to kick your Worship most inhumanly.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Kick Sir,

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, kick, 'tis a recreation I can shew you.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Sir, I am a free born Subject of England, and there are Laws, look you, there are Laws; so I say you are a Rascal again, and now how will you help your self? poor Fool!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Heark you Friend, have not you a Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: I have a Lady, Sir— oh and she's mightily taken with this Picture of yours, she was so mightily proud of it, she could not forbear shewing it me, and telling too who 'twas sent it her.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And has she bin long a Gilt? has she practised the Trade for any time?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Trade! humph, what Trade! what Trade? Friend?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why the Trade of Whore and no Whore, Catterwauling in jest, putting out Christian Colours, when she's a Turk under Deck: A curse upon all honest women in the flesh, that are Whores in the Spirit.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Poor Divil, how he rails, ha, ha, ha, look you sweet Soul, as I told you before, there are laws, there are laws, but those are things not worthy your consideration: Beautie's your business; but dear vagabond trouble thy self no further about my Spouse, let my Doxie rest in peace, she's meat for thy Master, old boy; I have my belly full of her every Night.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, I wish all your noble Family hang'd from the bottom of my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Moreover Captain Swash I must tell you my Wife is an honest Woman, of a vertuous disposition, one that I have loved from her Infancy, and she deserves it by her faithful dealing in this affair, for that she has discover'd loyally to me the treacherous designs laid against her Chastity, and my Honour.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: By this light the Beast weeps.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Truly I cannot but weep for Joy; to think how happy I am in a sincere faithful and loving Yoke-fellow, she charg'd me too to tell you into the bargain, that she is sufficiently satisfied of the most secret wishes of your heart.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: And that 'tis her desire, that you wou'd trouble your self no more about the matter.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: But henceforward behave your self with such discretion as becomes a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Oh to be sure most exactly!

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: And let her alone to make the best use of those innocent Freedoms I allow her without putting her reputation in hazzard.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: As how I beseech you—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: By your impertinent and unseasonable address.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And this news you bring me by a particular commission from your sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Yea Friend I do, and she hopes you'l be sensible, Dear heart, of her good meaning by it: these were her very words, I neither add nor diminish, for plain dealing is my Mistresses Friend.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Then all the Curses I shall think on this twelve-month light on her, and as many more on the next Fool that gives credit to the Sex.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Well, certainly I am the happiest Toad; how melancholy the Munkey stands now? Poor Pug hast thou lost her?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: To be so sordid a Jilt, to betray me to such a Beast as that, can she have any good thoughts of such a Swine? Dam her, had she abus'd me handsomly it had never next me.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Now Sir with your permission I'l take my leave.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, If you were gon to the Devil, I shou'd think you very well dispos'd of.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: If you have any Letter, or other commendation to the Lady that was so charm'd with your Resemblance there, it shall be very faithfully conveyed by—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Fool.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Your humble Servant Sir, I'm gon, I shall disturb you no further, your most humble Servant Sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Now Poverty, Plague, Pox and Prison fall thick upon the head of thee Fourbin.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Sir!—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Thou hast been an extraordinary Rogue in thy time.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: I hope I haue lost nothing in your Honours service Sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Find cut some way to revenge me on this old Rascal, and if I do not make thee a Gentleman.—

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: That you have been pleas'd to do long ago, I thank you; for I am sure you have not left me one shilling in my pocket these two Months.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Here, here's for thee to Revel withall.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Will your Honour please to have his Throat cut?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Or would you have him decently hang'd at his own door, and then give out to the World he did it himself?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: That wou'd do very well.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Or I think [to proceed with more safety] a good stale Jakes were a very pretty expedient.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Excellent, excellent Fourbin.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Leave matters to my discretion, and if I do not—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I know thou wilt, go, go about it, prosper and be famous: now e're I dare venture to meet Courtin again. will I go by my self, rail for an hour or two, and then be good company.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Take my word Sir, you had better give this business over, I tell you there's nothing in the World turns my Stomack so much as the man, that man that makes Love to me. I never saw one of your Sex in my life make love, but he lookt so like an Ass all the while, that I blusht for him.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I am afraid your Ladyship then is one of those dangerous Creatures they call She-wits, who are always so mightily taken with admiring themselves: that nothing else is worth their notice.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Oh! who can be so dull not to be ravisht with that roysterous mein of yours? that russling Ayr in your gate, that seems to cry where e're you go, make room, here comes the Captain: that Face the which bids defiance to the Weather; bless us! if I were a poor Farmers wife in the Country now, and you wanted Quarters, how would it fright me? But as I am young, not very ugly, and one you never saw before, how lovingly it looks upon me.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Who can forbear to sigh, look pale and languish, where Beauty and wit unite both their forces to enslave a heart so tractable as mine is. First, for that modish swim of your Body, the victorious motion of your Arms and Head, the toss of your Fan, the glancing of the Eyes, bless us! If I were a dainty fine drest Coxcomb with a great Estate and a little or no wit, vanity in abundance, and good for nothing, how would they melt and soften me? but as I am a scandalous honest Rascal, not Fool enough to be your sport, nor rich enough to be your prey, how glotingly they look upon me!—

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Alas, alas! What pity 'tis your honesty should ever do you hurt, or your wit spoil your preferment.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Just as much fair Lady, as that your Beauty should make you be envied at, or your Vertue provoke scandal.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Well the more I look, the more I'm in love with you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: The more I look, the more I am out of Love with you.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: How my heart swels when I see you!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: How my Stomach rises when I'm near you!

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Nay, then let's bargain.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: With all my heart, what?

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Not to fall in love with each other, I assure you Monsiour Captain.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: But to hate one another constantly and cordially.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Always when you are drunk, I desire you to talk scandalously of me.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Ay, and when I am sober too, in return whereof when e're you see a coquet of your acquaintance, and I chance to be named, be sure you spit at the filthy remembrance, and rail at me as if you lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: In the next place, when e're we meet in the Mall, I desire you to humph, put out your Tongue, make ugly mouths, laugh aloud, and look back at me.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Which if I chance to do, be sure at next turning to pick up some tawdry sluttering Fop or another.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: That I made acquaintance with all at the Musique-meeting.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Right, Just such another Spark to saunter by your side with his Hat under his Arm.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Hearkning to all the bitter things I can say to be revenged:

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Whilst the dull Rogue dare not so much as grin to oblige you, for fear of being beaten for it, when he is out of his waiting.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Counterfeit your Letters from me.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: And you to be even with me for the scandal, publish to all the World I offered to marry you.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Oh hideous marriage '

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Horrid, horrid marriage!

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Name, name no more of it.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: At that sad word let's part.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Let's wish all men decrepid, dull and silley

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: And every woman old and ugly.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Adieu!—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Farewell!—

div.stage: Enter a young fellow, affectedly drest, several others with him.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Ah me, Mr. Frisk.!

sp.speaker: Frisk. Madamoisel, Silvia!
sp.p: sincerely as I hope to be sav'd, the Devil take me, Dam me Madam, who's that?

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, hea.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: True to thy failings always Woman, how naturally is the Sex fond of a Rogue! What a Monster was that for a Woman to delight in, now must I love her still, tho I know I am a Blockhead for't, and she'l use me like a block-head too, if I don't prevent her: what's to be done? I'l have three Whores a day, to keep Love out of my head. Enter Beaugard. Beaugard will met again, how go matters? Handsomly!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Oh very handsomly! had you but seen how hadsomly I was us'd just now, you would swear so, I have heard thee rail in my time, wou'd thou wouldst exercise thy talent a little at present.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: At what?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why canst thou over want a subject! rail at thy self, rail at me, I deserve to be raild at, see there, what thinkest thou of that Engine, that moving lump of filthiness miscall'd a Man.

div.stage: [A Clumsie fellow marches over the Stage drest like an Officer.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Curse on him for a Rogue, I know him.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: So▪

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: The Rascal was a Retailer of Ale but yesterday, and now he is an Officer and be hang'd; 'tis a dainty sight in a morning to see him with his Toes turn'd in, drawing his Leggs after him, at the head of a hundred lusty Fellows, some honest Gentleman or other stays ●ow, because that Dog had money to bribe some corrupt Collonel withal.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: There, there's another of my acquaintance, he was my Fathers Footman not long since, and has pimpt for me oftner than he pray'd for himself; that good quality recommended him to a noble mans service, which together with flattering, fawning, lying, spying and informing, has rais'd him to an imployment of trust and reputation, though the Rogue can't write his Name, nor read his neck Verse, if he had occasion.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: 'Tis as unreasonable to expect a man of Sense should be prefer'd, as 'tis to think a Hector can be stout, a Priest religious, a fair Woman chast, or a pardon'd Rebel loyal.

div.stage: Enter two more seeming earnestly in discourse.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: That's seasonably thought on, look there, observe but that Fellow on the right hand, the Rogue with the busiest Face of the two, I'l tell thee his History.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I hope hanging will be the end of his History, so well I like him at the first sight.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: He was born a Vagabond, and no Parish own'd him, his Father was as obscure as his Mother publick, every body knew her, and no body could guess at him.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: He comes of a very good Family, heaven be prais'd.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: The first thing he chose to rise by, was Rebellion, so a Rebel he grew, and ●●ourisht a Rebel, fought against his King, and helpt to bring him to the Block:

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: And was he not Religious too?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Most devoutly! He could pray till he cry'd, and preach till he foam'd, which excellent Tallent made him popular, and at last prefer'd him to be a worthy Member of that never to be forgotten Rump Parliament.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Tray Sir be uncovered at that, and remember it with Reverence.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: In short, he was Committee man, Sequestrator and persecutor General of a whole County, by which he got enough at the Kings Return to secure himself in the general Pardon.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Naufeous Vermin: That such a Swine with the mark of Rebellion in his Forehead, should wallow in his Luxury whilst honest men are forgotten!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Thus forgiven, thus rais'd, and made thus happy, the ungrateful Slave disowns the hand that healed him, cherishes Factions to affront his Master, and once more would Rebel against the Head, which so lately saved his from a Pole.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What a dreadful Beard and swinging Sword he wears▪

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: 'Tis to keep his Cowardize in countenance, the Rascal will endure kicking most temperately for all that, I know five or six more of the same stamp; that never came abroad without terrible long Spits by their sides, with which they will let you bore their own Noses if you please, but let the Villain be forgotten.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: His Co-Rogue I have some knowledge of, he's a tatter'd worm-eaten Case-putter, some call him Lawyer, one that takes it very ill he is not made a Judg.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Yes, and is always repineing that men of parts are not regarded.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: He has been a great noise-maker in factious Clubs these seven years, and now I suppose is courting that Worshipful Rascal to make him Recorder of some factious Town.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: To teach Tallow-chandlers and Chees-mongers how far they may rebel against their King by vertue of Magna Chart●

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: But friend Beaugard methinks thou art very spleenatick of a sudden, how goes the affair of Love foreward, prosperously hah!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Oh I assure you most Triumphantly, Just now you must know I am parted with the sweet civil inchanted Ladies Husband.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Well and what says the Cuckold is he very kind and good natur'd as Cuckolds use to be?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why he says, Courtine in short, that I am a very silly fellow, (and truly I am very apt to believe him) and that I have been Jilted in this affair most unconscionably, a Plague on all P●mps, say, a mans business never thrives so well, as when he is his own Sollicitor.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Hist▪ hist. Capt. Capt. Capt. Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Run and get two Chairs presently, besure you get two Chairs, Sirrah, do you here? here's luck, here's luck, now or never Capt. never if not now Captain! here's luck.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir Iolly, no more adventures sweet Sir Iolly, I am like to have a very sine time o●'t truly.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly▪
sp.p:
The best in the World dear Dog, the very best in the
World, 's bud she's here hard by man, stays on purpose for thee finely disguis'd, the Cuckold has lost her too; and no body knows any thing of the matter but I, no body but I, and I you must know, I am I, hah! and I you little Toad, hah!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You are a very fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: The best natur'd Fellow in the World I believe of my years! now does my heart so thump for fear this business should miscarry; why I'l warrant thee, the Lady is here man, she's all thy own, 'tis thy own fault if thou art not in terra incognita within this half hour: come along prithee come along, fie for shame, what make a Lady loose her longing, come along I say, you— out upon't.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir your humble, I shan't stir.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: What? not go!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: No Sir, no Lady for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Not go! I should laugh at that Faith.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: No, I will assure you, not go Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Away you Wag, you jest, you jest you wag; not go quotha?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: No Sir, not go I tell you, what the Devil would you have more.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing Sir, but I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: And do you think then that I'l be us'd thus.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Take away my Reputation and take away my Life; I shall be disgrac't for ever.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I have not wrong'd you Sir Iolly.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Not wrong'd me! But you shall find you have wrong'd me, and wrong'd a sweet Lady, and a fine Lady:— I shall never be trusted again! never have employment more! I shall dye of the Spleen— prithee now be good natur'd, prithee be perswaded, od I'l give thee this Ring, I'l give thee this Watch, 'tis Gold, I'l give thee any thing in the World, go.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Not one Foot Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Now that I durst but murder him— well, shall I fetch her to thee? What shall I do for thee?
'Ods fish here she comes her self, now you ill natur'd Chunl, now you Devil, look upon her, do but look upon her, what shall I say to her?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: E'en what you please Sir Iolly.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p:
'tis a very strange Monster this— Madam this is the Gentleman, that's he, though (as one may say) he's something bashful, but I'l tell him who you are [goes to Beaugard.
If thou art not more cruel then Leopards, Lyone, Tygers, Wolves, or Tarters don't break my Heart, don't kill me, this unkindness of thine goes to the Soul of me. [goes to the Lady.
Madam, he says, he's so amazed at your Triumphant Beauty, that he dares not approach the excellence that shines from you.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: What can be the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Art thou then resolv'd to be remorseless? canst thou be insensible, hast thou Eyes? hast thou a Heart? hast thou any thing thou should'st have? cdd I'l tickle thee, get you to her you Fool, get you to her, to her; to her, to her, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Have you forgot me Beaugard?

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: So now to her agen I say, to her, to her and be hang'd, Ah Rogue! Ah Rogue! now, now, have at her, now have at her, there it goes, their it goes, Hey— Boys!—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Methinks this Face should not so much be alter'd, as to be nothing like what once I thought it, the object of your Pleasure and subject of your Praises.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Cunning Toad! Wheadling Jade! you shall see now how by degrees she'l draw him into the Whirl pool of Love, now he leers upon her, now he deers upon her, Oh law! there's Eyes! there's your Eyes! I must pinch him by the Calf of the Legg.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Madam, I must confess I do remember, that I had once acquaintance with a Face, whose Air and Beauty much resembled yours, and if I may trust my Heart, you are call'd Clarianda.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Clarinda. I was call'd till my ill Fortune Wedded me, now you may have heard of me by another Title, your friend there I suppose, has made nothing a secret to you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And are you then that kind inchanted fair one who was so passionately in Love with my Picture, that you could not forbear betraying me to the Beast your Husband, and wrong the Passion of a Gentleman that languisht for you, only to make your Monster merry, hark you Madam, had your fool bin worth it, I had beaten him, and have a Months mind to be exercising my parts that way upon your go between, your Male-Bawd there.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Ah Lord! Ah Lord! All's spoyl'd agen, all's ruin'd. I shall be undone for ever, why what a Devil is the matter now? what have I done? what sins have I committed.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: And are you that passionate Adorer of our Sex? who cannot Live a Week in London without Loving, are you the Spark that send you Picture up and down to longing Ladies, longing for a pattern of your Person.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Yes Madam when I receive so good Hostages as these are [shows the Gold. that it shall be well us'd, cou'd you find out no body but me to play the Fool withal.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: A lack a day!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Could you pitch upon no Body but that wretched Woman, that has loved you too well to abuse you thus?

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Thatever I was Born!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Here, here Madam, I'l return you your dirt, I scorn your Wages, as I do your Service.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Fye for shame what refund? That is not like a Souldier to refund, keep, keep it to pay your Sempstress withal.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: His Sempstress, who the Devil is his Sempstress? Odd what wou'd I give to know that now!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: There was a Ring too, which I sent you this Afternoon, if that fit not your Finger, you may dispose of it some other way, where it may give no occasion of Scandal, and you'l do well.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: A Ring Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: A small triffl●, I suppose Sir David deliver'd it to you when he return'd you your Mignature.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I beseech you Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Farewel you Traytor.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: As I hope to be sav'd, and upon the word of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Go you are a falfe ungrateful Brute, and trouble me no more.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir Iolly, Sir Iolly, Sir Iolly.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Ah thou Rebel!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Some advice, some advice, dear Friend e're I'm ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Ev'n two pennyworth of Hemp for your Honours supper that's all the remedy that I know.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But prithee hear a little reason.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: No Sir I ha' done, no more to be said, I ha' done, I am asham'd of you, I'l have no more to say to you, I'l never see your Face again, good b'w'y.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Death and the Devil, what have my Stars been doing to day! a Ring!— deliver'd by Sir David!— what can that mean?— Pox on her for a Jilt, she lies, and has a mind to amuse and laugh at me a day or two longer, hist▪ here comes her Beast once more; I'I use him Civilly, and try what Discovery I can make.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! here's the Captains Jewel, very well: In troth I had like to have forgotten it, Ha, ha, ha,— how damnable Mad he'l be now, when I shall deliver him his Ring again, ha ha!— Poor Dog he'l hang himself at least, ha, ha, ha,— Faith, 'tis a very pretty Stone, and finely set: Humph! if I should keep it now!— I'll say I have lost it, no I'l give it him again, o' purpose to vex him, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir David, I am heartily sorrie.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Oh Sir, 'tis you I was seeking for, ha, ha, ha, what shall I say to him now to terrifie him?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Me, Sir!—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ay, you Sir, if your name be Captain Beaugard: how like a Fool he looks already?—

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: What you please, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Sir, I should speak a word with you, if you think fit, what shall I do now to keep my countenance.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Can I be so happy, Sir, as to be able to serve you in any thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: No Sir, ha, ha, ha, I have commands of service to you Sir, oh Lord! ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ay Sir, you Sir, but put on your hat, Friend, put on your hat, be cover'd.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, will you please to sit down on this bank?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: No, no, there's no need, no need, for all I have a young Wife I can stand upon my legs, Sweet-heart.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you!

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: By no means, I think friend, we had some hard words just now, 'twas about a paultry baggage, but she's a pretty baggage and a witty baggage, and a baggage that—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, I am heartily asham'd of all misdemeanour on my side.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: You do well, though are not you a damn'd Whore-master, a devilish Cuckold-making fellow? here, here, do you see this? here's the Ring you sent a Roguing; Sir, do you think my Wife wants any thing that you can help her too?— Why I'll warrant this Ring cost fifty pound: What a prodigal Fellow are you to throw a way so much monie; or didst thou steal it old Boy? I believe thou maist be poor I'll lend thee money upon't, if thou thinkst fit at thirty in the hundred, because I love thee, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, your humble Servant, I am sorry 'twas not worth your Ladies acceptance, now what a dog am I!

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: I should have given it thee before, but faith I forgot it, though it was not my Wives fault in the least, for she says as thou likest this usage, she hopes to have thy custom again Child; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Then Sir, I beseech you tell her, that you have made a Convert on me, and that I am so sensible of my insolent behaviour towards her—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Very well, I shall do it.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: That 'tis impossible I shall ever be at peace with my self till I find some way how I may make her reparation.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Very good, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And that if ever she find me guilty of the like offence again.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: No Sir, you had not best, proceed, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Let her banish all good opinion of me for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: No more to be said, your Servant, good b'w'y.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: One word more, I beseech you, Sir Davy.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I beg you tell her that the generous reproof she has given me has so wrought upon me—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Well, I will:

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: That I esteem this Jewel, not only as a wreck redeem'd from my folly, but that for her sake I will preserve it to the utmost moment of my life.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: With all my heart, I vow and swear.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And that I long to convince her I am not the Brute she might mistake me for.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Right; well, this will make the purest sport, (Aside;) let me see, first you acknowledge your self to be a very impudent Fellow.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I do so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: And that you shall never be at rest, till you have satisfi'd my Lady.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Right, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Satisfi'd her, very good, ha, ha, ha, and that you will never play the fool any more, be sure you keep your word, Friend.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Never, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: And that you will keep that Ring for her sake, as long as you live, hah!—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: To the day of my death, I'll assure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: I protest that will be very kindly done— and that you long mightily, long, to let her understand that you are another guess Fellow than she may take you for.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Exactly Sir, that is the sum and end of my desires.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Well, I'll take care of your business, I'll do your business, I'll warrant you, this will make the purest sport when I come home, no, (Aside) Well your Servant, remember, be sure you remember, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: So, now I find a Husband is a delicate instrument rightly made use of;— To make her old jealous Coxcomb pimp for me himself, I think 'tis as worthy an emploiment as such a noble Consort can be put to.
sp.l: Ah were ye all such Husbands and such Wives,
We younger Brothers shou'd lead better lives.

div.head: Act. III.
SCENE Covent-Garden.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: TO fall in love, and to fall in love with a Souldier! nay, a disbandded Souldier too, a fellow with the mark of Cain upon him, which every body knows him by, and is ready to throw stones at him for.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Dam her, I shall never enjoy her without ravishing; if she, were but very rich and very ugly, I wou'd marry her: Ay, 'tis she, I know her mischievous look too well to be mistaken in it,— Madam!—

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: 'Tis a very hard Case, that you have resolv'd not to let me be quiet.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: 'Tis very unreasonably done of you, Sir, to haunt me up and down every where at this scandalous rate, the world will think we are acquainted shortly.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: But, Madam, I shall fairly take more care of my Reputation, on, and from this time forward shun and avoid you most watchfully.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Have you not haunted this place these two hours.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: 'Twas because I knew it to be your Ladyships home then, and therefore might reasonably be the place you least of all frequented, one would imagine you were gone a Coxcomb-hunting by this time, to some place of publick appearance or other, 'tis pretty near the hour, twill be twilight presently, and then the Owles come all abroad.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: What need I take the trouble to go so far a fowling when there's game enough at our own doors.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: What game for your Net, fair Ladie.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Yes, or any womans Net else, that will spread it.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: To shew you how despicablie I think of the business, I will here leave you presently, though I lose the pleasure of railing at you.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Do so I wou'd advise you; your raillery betrays your wit, as bad as your clumsey civility does your breeding.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Adieu!—

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Farewel!—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Why do not you go about your business?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Because I wou'd be sure to be rid of you first, that you might not dog me.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Were it but possible that you cou'd answer me one question truly, and then I should be satisfi'd.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Any thing for composition to be rid of you handsomly.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Are you really very honest? Look in my Face and tell me that.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Look in your Face and tell you, for what? To spoil my Stomach to my Supper.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: No, but to get thee a Stomach to thy Bed, Sweet-heart, I would if possible be better acquainted with thee because thou art very ill-natur'd.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Your only way to bring that business about effectually, is to be more troublesome, and if you think it worth your while to be abus'd substantially; you may make your personal appearance this Night.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: How? where? and when? and what hour I beseech thee?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Under the Window, between the hours of eleven and twelve exactly.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Where shall these lovely Eyes, and Ears hear my Plaints and see my Tears.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: At that kind hour thy griefs shall end if thou canst know thy Foe from thy Friend.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Here's another trick of the Devil now, under that Window between the hours of eleven and twelve exactly, I am a damn'd Fool, and must go, let me see, suppose I meet with a lusty beating! pish, that's nothing for a man that's in love, or suppose she contrive some way to make a publick Coxcomb of me, and expose me to the scorn of the World, for an example to all amorous Block-heads hereafter? why, if she do, I'l swear I have lain with her, beat her Relations, if they pretend to Vindicate her, and so there's one love intrigue pretty well over.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Go get you in to your Ladie now, and tell her, I am comeing.

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: Her Ladiship, Right-worshipful is pleas'd not to be at home.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: How's that? my Ladie not at home! run, run in and ask when she went forth, whether she is gone, and who is with her, run and ask, Vermin.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: She went out in her Chair presently after you this After-noon.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Then I may be a Cuckold still for ought I know, what will be comeof me? I have surely lost, and ne'r shall find her more, she promis'd me strictlie to stay at home, till I came back again; for ought I know she may be up three pair of stairs in the Temple now.

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: Is her Ladyship in Law then, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Or it may be taking the Air as far as Knights-bridge with some smooth fac'd Rogue or another: 'tis a damn'd house, that Swan, that Swan at Knights-bridge is a confounded house, Vermin.

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: Do you think she is there then?—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: No, I do not think she is there neither; but such a thing may be, you know; would that Barn-Elms was under water too, there's a 1000 Cuckolds a Year made at Barn-Elms, by Rosamonds ponds, the devil if she shou'd be there this evening, my heart's broke.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: That must be Sir Davy; Ay, that's he, that's he, ha, ha, ha, was ever the like heard of? was ever any thing so pleasant?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: I'll lock her up three daies, and three nights, without meat, drink or light, I'll humble her in the Devils name.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Well, cou'd I but meet my Friend, Sir Davy, it wou'd be the joyfullest news for him—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Who's there that has any thing to say to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Ah my Friends, of Friends, such news, such tidings.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: I have lost my Wife Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Lost her! She's not dead I hope.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Yes, Alas, she's dead, irrecoverably lost.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Why I parted with her within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Did you so, are you sure it was she? where was it? I'll have my Lord-Chief-Justices Warrant and a Constable presentlie.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: And she made the purest sport now, with a Young Fellow, Man, that she met withall accidentally.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Oh Lord! that's worse and worse, a Young fellow!— my Wife making sport with a young fellow! oh Lord! here are doings! here are vagaries! I'll run mad, I'll climb Bow Steeple presently, bestride the Dragon, and preach Cuckoldom to the whole City.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioll.
sp.p: The best of all was too, that it happen'd to be an Idle Coxcomb that pretended to be in lover with her Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Indeed! in love with her! who was it? what's his Name▪ I warrant you won't tell a Body,— I'll indite him in the Crown Office; no I'll issue Warrants to apprehend him for Treason upon the Statue of Edw. 19th. won't you tell me what young Fellow it was, was it a very handsome young Fellow, hah—

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Handsome? yes hang him the fellow's handsome enough; he is not very handsom neither, but he has a devillish leering black-eye.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Oh Lord?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p:
His face to is a good rideing Face, 'tis no foft effeminate complexion indeed, but his countenance is ruddy, sanguine and chearful,
a devillish fellow in a Corner, I'll warrant him.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Bless us! what will become of me, why the devil did I marry a young Wife? Is he very well shap'd too, tall, straight, and proportionable, hah!—

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Tall? No, he's not very tall neither, yet he is tall enough too, he's none of your overgrown lubberly Flanders Jades, but more of the true English breed, well knit, able, and fit for service old Boy; the Fellow is well shap'd truely, very well proportion'd, strong, and active; I have seen the Rogue leap like a Buck.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Who can this be? Well, and what think you, Friend, has he been there? Come, come, I'm sensible she's a young Woman, and I am an old Fellow, troth a very old Fellow, I signifie little or nothing now, but do you think he has prevailed? am I Cuckold, Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Cuckold! what! a Cuckold in Covent-garden? No I'll assure you, I believe her to be the most vertuous Woman in the World; but if you had but seen!—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ay, wou'd I had, what was it?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: How like a Rogue she us'd him: First of all comes me up the Spark to her, Madam, says he— and then he bows down, thus— how now, says she, what would the impertient Fellow have.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Humph! ha! well, and what then?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Madam, says he again (bowing as he did before) my heart is so entirely yours, that except you take pitie of my sufferings I must here dy at your Feet.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: So, and what said she again, Neighbour? ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Go, you are a Fop.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, did she indeed? Did she say so indeed? I am glad on 't, troth I am very glad on't; well, and what next? And how, and well, and what? ha!—

sp.speaker: Sir Ibl.
