sp.p: Madam, says he, this won't do; I am your humble Servant, for all this, you may pretend to be as ill-natur'd as you please, but I shall make bold.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Was there ever such an impudent Fellow?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: With that, Sirrah, says she, you are a sawsi● Jackanapes and I'll have you kickt.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Well I wou'd not be unmarri'd agam to be an Angel.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: But the best Jeast of all was, who this should be at last.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ay, who indeed! I'll warrant you some silly Fellow or other; poor Fool!

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p:
E'en a scandalous Rake hell, that lingers up and down the Town by the Name of Captain Beaugard▪ but he has been a bloody
Cuckold-making Scoundrel in his time.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Hang him Sot, is it he? I don't value him thus, not a wet finger Man, to my knowledge she hates him, she scorns him Neighbour, I know it, I am very well satisfi'd in the point, besides I have seen him since that, and out-hector'd him: I am to tell her from his own mouth, that he promises never to affront her more.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ay, Ay—

div.stage: Enter Lady Dunce, paying her Chairman.

sp.speaker: Chairman.
sp.p: God bless you, Madam, thank your Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Hush, hush, there's my Lady, I'll be gone, I'll not be seen, your humble Servant, God b'w'y.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: No faith, Sir Iolly, e'en go into my house now, and stay Supper with me, we han't supt together a great while.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Hah! say you so, I don't care if I do, faith withall my heart; this may give me an opportunity to set all things right again.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: My Dear!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: You have been abroad, my Dear, Isee!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Only for a little Air, truly I was almost stiffled within doors, I hope you will not be angry, Sir David, will you?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Angry Child! no Child, not I; what should I be angry for!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I wonder Sir David, you will serve me at this rate. Did you not promise me to go in my behalf to Beaugard and correct him according to my instructions for his insolence.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: So I did, Child; I have been with him, Sweet-heart, I have told him all to a tittle, I gave him back again the Picture too, but as the Devil would have it, I forgot the Ring, faith I did.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Did you purpose, Sir Sodom, to render me ridiculous to the man I abominate, what scandalous interpretation think you must he make of my retaining any trifle of his sent me on so dishonourable terms.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Really, my Lamb, thou art in the right, yet I went back afterwards, Dear-heart, and did the business to some purpose.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I am glad that you did with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: I gave him his lesson, I'll warrant him.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Lesson! what lesson had you to give him?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Why I told him as he lik'd that usage he might come again ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Ay, and so let him.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: With all my heart, I'll give him free leave or hang me: though thou wou'd'st not imagine how the poor Devil's alter'd. La you there now, but as certainly as I stand here, that man is troubled that he swears he shall not rest day nor night till he has satisfied thee; prithee be satisfi'd with him if 'tis possible, my Dear, prithee do, I promis'd him before I left him to tell thee as much, for the poor wretch looks so simply, I cou'd not chuse but pity him I vow and swear, ha, ha, ha,.

sp.speaker: Iol.
sp.p: Now, now, you little Witch, now you Chitsface, odd I cou'd find in my heart to put my little Finger in your Bubbies.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Sir Da. I must tell you, that I cannot but resent your so soon reconcilement with a man that I hate worse then death, and that if you lov'd me with half that tenderness which you profess, you wou'd not forget an affront so palpably, and so basely offer'd me.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Why Chicken where's the remedy? what's to be done? how wouldst thou have me deal with him?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Bless us for ever? cut his throat? what do murder?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Murder, yes, any thing to such an incorrigible Enemy of your honour, one that has resolv'd to persist in abusing of you, see here this letter this I received since I last parted with you just now it was thrown into my Chair by an impudent Lacquey of his, kept o' purpose for such imployments.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Let me see: A Letter indeed!— for the Lady Dunce— damn'd Rogue, treacherous dog, what can he say in the inside now, here's a Villian.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Yes, you had best break it open, you had so, 'tis like the rest of your discretion.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Lady, if I have an enemy it is best for me to know what mischief he intends me, therefore, with your leave I will break it open.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Do, do, to have him believe that I was pleas'd enough with it to do it my self, if you have the Spirit of a Gentleman in you, cary it back, and dash it as it is in the face of that audacious Fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: What can be the meaning of this now?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: A Gentleman, yes, Madam, I am a Gentleman, and the world shall find that I am a Gentleman— I have certainly the best Woman in the World.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: What do you think must be the end of all this? I have no refuge in the world, but your kindness, had I a Jealous Husband now, how miserable must my life be!

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Ah Rogues. Nose ah Devil! ah Toad! cunning Thief, wheed ling Slut, I'll bite lier by and by.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p:
Poor Fool! no Dear, I am not Jealous, nor never will
〈…〉 of thee: Do what thou wilt thou shalt not make me Jealous 〈◊〉 love thee too well to suspect thee.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Ah but how long will you do so?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: How long! as long as I live I warrant thee, I— don't talk to a body so: I cannot hold out if thou dost, my eyes will run over, poor 〈◊〉, poor Birdsnies! poor Lambki●●.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: But will you be so kind to me to answer my desires, will you once more endeavour to make that Traytor sensible that I have too just an esteem of you, not to vallue his addresses as they deserve.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, I will.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: But don't stay away too long Dear, make what haste you can I shall be in pain till I see you again.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: My hear, my Love, my Babby, I'll be with thee in a moment, how happy am I above the rest of men: Neighbour, dear Neighbour, walk in with my Wife, and keep her company, till I return again, Child don't be troubled, prithee don't be troubled, was there ever such a Wife, well da, da, da, don't be troubled, prithee, don't be troubled, prithee don't be troubled, Da, da,

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Sir Iolly, Sir Iolly, Sir Iolly.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Don't be troubled, prithee don't be trouled, da, da.

sp.speaker: Lady Du.
sp.p: But Sir Iolly, can you guess whereabout my wand'ring Officer may be probably found now?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Found Ladie? he is to be found, Madam, he is to be at my house presently Ladie, he's certainly one of the 〈◊〉 Fellows in the World.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: You speak like a Friend, Sir Iolly.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: His Friend, Lady; no Madam his Foe, his utter Enemy, I shall be his ruin, I shall undo him.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: You may, if you please, then come both and play at Dards this evening with me for an hour or two, for I have contriv'd it so that Sir David is to be abroad at Supper to night, he cannot possibly avoid it; I long to win some of the Captains Money strangely.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Do you so, my Gamester? Well, I'll besure to bring him, and for what he carries about him I'll warrant you— odd he's a pretty Fellow, a very pretty Fellow, he has only one fault.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: And what is that I beseech you Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Only too Loving, too good Natur'd, that's all; 'tis certainly the best natur'd Fool breathing, that's all his fault.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Hist, hist, I think I see company coming, if you please, Sir Iolly we'll go in.

div.stage: Enter Beaugard follow'd by Sir Davy, Vermin.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p:
Mum, mum, mum, 'tis he himself the very same; odds so
Sir Davy after him too, hush, hush, hush, let us be gone, let us retire, do but look upon him now, mind him a little, there's a 〈◊〉▪ there's an Air, there's a motion! Ah Rogue, ah Devil, get you in, get you in, I say there's a shape for you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: What the Divel shall I do to recover this days loss again, my honourable Pimp too, my Pander Knight has forsaken me, methinks I am quandari'd like one going with a party to discover the Enemies Camp; but had lost his guide upon the mountains: Curse on him, old Angus is here agen, there can be no good Fortune towards me when he's at my heels

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, Sir, one word with you Sir! Captain, Captain, noble Captain, oneword, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: With me Friend?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Yes with you, my no Friend.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir David my intimate my Bosom Physitian—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ah Rogue! damn'd Rogue!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: My Confessor, my dearest Friend, I ever had—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Dainty Wheadle, here's a Fellow for ye.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: One that has taught me to be in love with Vertue and shown me the ugly inside of my Follies.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Sir, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Is that all? if you are as cold in your Love as you are in your Friendship, Sir Davy, your Lady has the worst time o'nt of any one in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: So she has, Sir, when she cannot be free from the insolent solicitations of such Fellows as you are, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: As me, Sir? why who am I, good Sir Domine Doddle-pate?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: So take notice he threatens me, I'll have him bound to the peace instantly, will you never have remorse of Conscience Friend? have you banisht all shame from your Soul? Do you consider my name is Sir Davy Dunce? that I have the most vertuous Wife living: Do you consider that? Now, how like a Rogue he looks again; what a hang-dog leer was that?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Your vertuous Wife, Sir, you are always harping upon that string Sir Davy.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: No 'tis you wou'd be harping upon that string, Sir, see you this? cast your eyes upon this, this Letter Sir, did not you promise this very day, to abandon all manner of proceedings of this Nature tending to the dishonour of me and my Family?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Letter, Sir? what the divel does he mean now? Let me see, For the Lady Dunce, this is no scrawl of mine, I'll be Sworn by Iove her own hand! What a Dog was I! forty to one but I had play'd the Fool, and spoil'd all again; was there ever so Charming a Creature breathing— did your Lady deliver this to your hands Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p:
Ev'n her own self in person, Sir, and bad me tell you Sir,
that she has too just an esteem of me Sir, not to vallue such a Fellow as you are as you deserve.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Very good: (Reads the Letter) I doubt not but this Letter will surprize you— (in troth, and so it does extreamly) but reflect upon the manner of conveighing it to your hand as kindly as you can.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ay a damn'd Thief to have it thrown into the Chair by a Footman.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: (Reads) Would Sir Davy were but half so kind to you as I am.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Say you so you insinuating Knave.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But he I am satisfi'd is so severely Jealous, that except you contrive some way to let me see you this evening: I fear all will be hopeless

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Impudent Traytor I might have been a Monster yet before I had got my Supper in my Belly.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: In order to which either appear your self, or some body for you, half an hour hence in the Piazza, where more may be considered of, adieu.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Thanks to you noble Sir, with all my heart, you are come I see accordingly, but as a Friend I am bound in Conscience to tell the business won't do, the trick won't pass Friend, you may put up your Pipes, and march off! Oh Lord! he lye with my Wife, Pug●●● he make Sir Davy Dunce a Cuckold, poor wretch, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Hist, hist, hist.

div.stage: Enter Lady Dunce, and Fourbin disguisd.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: That's he, there he is! succeed and be rewarded.

sp.speaker: Four.
sp.p: Other people may think what they please; but in my own opinion, I am a very pretty Fellow now, if my design but succeed upon this old Baboon, I'll be canoniz'd Sir, Sir, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Friend! with me? Wou'd you speak with me, Friend.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Sir, my commands were to attend your Worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Beaugard, Beaugard, hist, hist, here here, quickly hist.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Where do you live, Sweet-heart, and who do you belong too?

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Sir I am a small Instrument of the City, I serve the Lord Mayor in his Office there.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: How the Lord Mayor!

sp.speaker: Four.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, who desires you by all means to do him the Honour of your company at supper this evening.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: It will be the greatest honour I ever received in my Life, what my Lord Mayor Invite me to supper? I am his Lordships most humble servant.

sp.speaker: Four.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, if your name be Sir Davy Dunce, as I have the honour to be inform'd it is, he desires you moreover to make what haste you can, for that he has some matters of importance to communicate to your honour which may take up some time.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I hope it will succeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Communicate with me, he does me too noble a favour, 〈◊〉 upon the wings of Ambition to say my self at his Footstool; My Lord-Mayor sends himself to invite me to Supper, to confer with me too: I shall certainly be a great Man.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: What Answer will your Worship charge me back withal?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Let his Lordship know that I am amazed, and confounded, at his generosity, and that I am so transported with the honour he does me, that I will not fail to wait on him in the roasting of an Egg.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: I am your Worships lowly Slave.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Vermin, go get the Coach ready, get me the Gold Medal too and Chain which I took from the Roman Catholik Officer for a Popish Relick; I'l be fine, I'l shine and drink Wine that's Divine, My Lord-Mayor invite me to Supper!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: My Dearest, I'm glad to see thee return'd in safety from the bottom of my heart, hast thou seen the Traitor?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Seen him? hang him, I have seen him, Pox on him, seen him.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Well, and what is become of him! Where is he?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Why dost thou ask me where he is? what a Pox care I what becomes of him, prithee don't trouble me with thy impertinence, I am busie.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: You are not Angry, my Dear, are you?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: No, but I am pleas'd, and that's all one, very much pleas'd let me tell you, but that I am only to Sup with my Lord-Mayor, that's all, nothing else in the World, only the business of the Nation calls upon me, that's all, therefore once more I say don't be troublesome, but stand off.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: You always think my company troublesome, you never stay at home to comfort me, what think you I shall do alone by my self all this Evening? mopeing in my Chamber, pray my Joy stay with me for once; I hope he won't take me at my word.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: I say again and again, Tempter stand off, I will not lose my preferment for my pleasure, Honour is towards me, and slesh and blood are my Averllon.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: But how long will you stay then?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: I don't know, may be not an hour, may be all night, as his Lordship and I think fit, what's that to any body.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: You are very cruel to me▪

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: I can't help it, go get you in and pass away the time with your Neighbour, I'l be back again before I die, in the mean time be humble and conformable, go: is the Coach ready?

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Well, your Servant, what nothing to my Lady Mayoress! you have a great deal of Breeding indeed, a great deal, nothing to my Lady Mayoress?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: My service to her, if you please.

sp.speaker: Sir D.
sp.p: Well, Da, da, the poor fool cries o' my conscience! Adieu, do you hear, farewell.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: As well as what I love can make me.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Madam, is he gone.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: In post haste I assure.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: In troth and joy go with him.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Do you then, Sir Iolly, conduct the Captain hither, whilst I go and dispose of the Family that we may be private.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Troth I had forgot my Medal and Chain, quite and clean, forgot my Relique, I was forced to come up these back stairs, for fear of meeting my Wife again, it is the troublesom'st loving Fool, I must into my Closet and write a short Letter too, 'tis Post night, I had forgot that▪ well, I would not have my Wife catch me for a Guinny.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Are you very certain, Madam, no body is this way? I fancy as we enter'd I saw the glimpse of something more than ordinary.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Is it your care of me? or your personal fears, that make you so supsitious, whereabouts was the Apparition?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: There, there, just at the very door.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Fie for shame, that's Sir Davy's Closet, and he I am satisfi'd is far enough off by this time, I'm sure I heard the Coach drive him away. But to convince you, you shall see now; Sir Davy, Sir Davy, Sir Davy, [knocking at the Closet door] look you there, you a Captain and afraid of a shadow, come Sir, shall we call for the Gards?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And what shall we play for pretty One!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Ee'n what you think best, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Silver Kisses or Golden Joyes! come let us make Stakes a little.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Ah Rogue, ah Rogue! are you there? have I caught you in Faith now, now, now!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: And who shall keep them?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You, till Sir Davy, returns from Supper.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: That may be long enough, for our Engine Fourbin has Orders not to give him over suddenly I assure you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And is't to your self then I'm oblig'd for this blest opportunity? Let us improve it to Love's best advantage.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Ah, h, h, h! Ah, h, h, h!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Let's vow eternal, and raise our thoughts, to ' expectation of immortal pleasures, in one anothers eyes let's read our joyes till we've no longer power o're our desires, drunk with this dissolving, oh!—

div.stage: Enter Sir Davy from his Closet.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: By this light the Cuckold, Presto. nay then Hallo.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Oh Lord, a Man! a Man in my Wife's Chamber; Murder, Murder, Thieves, Thieves, shut up my Doors! Madam! Madam! Madam!

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, Theives, Thieves, urder, Murder, where Neighbour, where, where?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Pierce, pierce this wretched Heart hard to the Hilts, dye this in deepest crimson of my Blood, spare not a miserable Womans life, whom Heav'n design'd to be the unhappy object of the most horrid usage Man e'r acted.

div.stage: Catches up Beaugard's sword which he had left behind him in the burry, and presents it to Sir Davy.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: What in the name of Satan does she mean now?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Curse on my fatal beauty! blasted ever be these two baneful eyes, that could inspire a barbarous Villain to attempt such crimes as all my blood's too little to attone for: Nay, you shall hear me.—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Hear you, Madam? No, I have seen too much I thank you heartily, hear you Quotha!—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Yes, and before I die too I'l be justified.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Justifi'd, oh Lord, justifi'd!—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Notice being given me of your return, I came with speed to this unhappy place, where I have oft been blest with your Embraces, when from behind the Arras out starts Beaugard; how he came there heav'n knows.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: I'l have him hang'd for Burglary, he has broken my House, and broke the Peace upon my Wife, very good!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Straight in his Arms he graspt me fast, with much ado I, plung'd and got my freedom, ran to your Closet door, knock● and implor'd your aid, call'd on your name, but all in vain—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Soon again he seiz'd me, stopt my mouth, and with a Conquerors fury—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Oh Lord! oh Lord! no more, no more, I beseech thee, I shall grow mad, I will grow mad, and very mad, I'l plough up Rocks and Adamantine Iron bars, I'l crack the frame of nature, sally out like Tamberlain upon the Trojan Horse, and drive the Pigmies all like Geese before me; Oh Lord stop her mouth! well▪ and how? and what then I stopt thy mouth! well! hah!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: No, though unfortunate I still am innocent, his oursed purpose could not be accomplisht, but who will live so injur'd? No I'l die to be reveng'd on my self, I ne'r can hope that I may see his streaming Offers to run upon the sword. gore: and thus I let out my own—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ha! what wouldst thou do my love, prithy don't break my heart,? If thou wilt kill, kill me; I know thou art innocent, I see thou art; though I had rather be a Cuckold a thousand times than loose thee, poor Love, poor Dearee, poor Baby.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Alack a day—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Ah me!—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ah, prithee be comforted now, prithee do, why I'l love thee the better for this, for all this Mun, why shouldst he troubled for anothers Ill doings! I know it was no fault of thine.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: No, no more it was not I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: See, see, my Neighbour weeps too, he's troubled to see thee thus.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Oh, but revenge!

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Why thou shalt have revenge, I'l have him murderd, I'l have his throat cut before to morrow morning Child, rise now, prithee rise.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Ay do Madam, and smile upon Sir Davy.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: But will you love me then as well as e're you did?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ay, and the longest day I live too.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: And shall I have Justice done me on that prodigious Monster?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Why, he shall be Crows meat by to morrow night, I tell thee he shall be Crows meat by midnight Chicken.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Then I will live, since so 'tis something pleasant. When I in Peace may lead a happy Life, With such a Husband—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: I with such a Wife.

div.head: ACT. IV.
SCENE The Tavern.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: WElcome Gentlemen, very welcome Sir: will you please to walk up one pair of stairs.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Get the great Room ready presently, carry up too a good stock of Bottles before hand, with Ice to cool our Wine, and Water to refresh our Glasses.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: It shall be done Sir; Coming, coming there, Coming: speak up in the Dolphin some body.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Ah Courtine, must we be always idle I must we never see our glorious days again? when shall we be rowling in the Lands of Milk and Honey▪ incampt in large luxuriant Vineyards, where the loadded Vines Cluster about our Tents, drink the rich Juice, just prest from the plump Grape, feeding on all the fragrant golden Fruit that grow in fertile Climes, and ripen'd by the earliest vigour of the Sun.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Ah Beaugard! those days have been, but now we must resolve to content our selves at an humble rate: methinks it is not unpleasant to consider how I have seen thee in a large Pavillion; drowning the heat of the day in Campagne Wines, sparkling sweet as those charming Beauties, whose dear remembrance every glass recorded, with half a dozen honest Fellows more, Friends Beaugard, faithful hearty Friends, things as hard to meet with as preferment here: Fellows that would speak truth boldly, and were proud on't, that scorn'd flattery, love'd honesty; for 'twas their portion, and never yet learn'd the Trade of case and lying, but now.—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Ay, now we are at home in our natural Hives, and sleep like Drones; but there's a Gentleman on the other side the Water, that may make work for us all one day.

sp.speaker: Gour.
sp.p: But in the mean while—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: In the mean while patience, Courtine, that is the English mans Vertue: Go to the man that ows you money, and tell him your are necessitated, his answer shall be, a little patience I beseech you, Sir: Ask a Cowardly Rascal satisfaction for a sordid injury done you, he shall cry, alas a day, Sir, you are the strangest Man living, you won't have patience to hear one speak: Co●● 〈◊〉 to a great Man that you want preferment, that you have forsa●●●●●siderable advantages abroad, in obedience to publick 〈◊〉 all you shall get of him is this, you must have patience, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: But will patience feed me, or cloath me, or keep 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Prithee no more hints of Poverty: 'tis scandalous, 's Death I wou'd as soon chuse to hear a Souldier brag as complain, dost thou want any Money?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: True indeed I want no necessaries to keep me alive; but I do not enjoy my self with that freedom I wou'd do, there is no more pleasure in living at stint, then there is in living alone. I wou'd have it in my power (when he needed me) to serve and assist my Friend, I would to my Ability deal handsomely too be the Woman that pleased me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Oh ●fy for shame! you wou'd be a Whoremaster, Friend, go, go, I'l have no more to do with you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I wou'd not be forced neither at any time to avoid a Gentleman that had obliged me, for want of Money to pay him a debt contracted in our old acquaintance, it turns my Stomach to wheadle with the Rogue I scorn when he uses me Scurvily, because he has my Name in his Shop-Book.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: As for example, to indure the familiaritys of a Rogue, that shall cock his greasy Hat in my Face, when he duns me, and at the same time vail it to an overgrown Deputy of the Ward, though a drowzy Fellmonger.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: To be forced to concurr with his Non-sence too, and laugh at his Parish Jests.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: To use respects and ceremonies to the Milch-Cow his Wife, and praise her pretty Children, though they stink of their Mother, and are uglier than the issue of a Baboon, yet all this must be endured.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Must it Beaugard.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And since 'tis so let's think of a Bottle.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: With all my Heart, for rayling and drinking do much better together then by themselves; a private room, a trusty Friend or two, good Wine and bold Truths, are my happiness; but where's our dear Friend and intimate, Sir Iolly, this Evening.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: To deal like a friend Courtine, I parted with him but just now, he's gone to contrive me a meeting is possible this ●ight with the Woman my Soul is most fond of: I was this Evening just entering upon the Pallace of all Joy, when I met with so damnably a disappointment— in short, that Plague to all Well meaning Women, the Husband came unseasonably and sorc't a poor Lover to this Heels that was fairly making his progress another way Courtine, the Story thou shalt here more at large hereafter.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: A Plague on him, why didst thou not Murder the presumptious Cuckold? saucy intruding Clown? to dare to disturb a Gentleman's privacies, I would have beaten him into Sence of his trangression; injoy'd his Wife before his Face, and a taught the Dog his Duty.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p:
Look you Courtine, you think you are dealing with the Landlord of your Winter Quarters in Alsatia now? friend, friend,
there is a difference between a freeborn English Cuckold, and a sheaking Wittal of a Conquered Province.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh by all means! there ought to be a difference observed between your arbitrary Whoring and your limited Fornication.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And but reason: for though we may make bold with another mans Wife in a friendly way: yet nothing upon compulsion Dear-heart.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: And now Sir Iolly, I hope is to be the instrument of some immortal Plot, some contrivance for the good of thy body, and the old fellows soul Beaugard, for all Cuckolds go to Heaven, that's most certain.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir Iolly! Why on my Conscience he thinks it as much his undoubted Right to be Pimp Master-General to London and Middlesex, as the Estate he possesses is, by my consent his worship should, e'en have a Pattent for it.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: He is certainly the fittest for the imployment in Christendome; he knows more Families by their Names and Titles, than all the Bellmen within and without the walls.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Nay he keeps a Catalogue of the choicest Beauties about Town, illustrated with a particular account of their Age, Shape, proportion, colour of Hair and Eyes, degrees of Complexion, Gunpowder Spots and Moles.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I wish the old Pander were bound to satisfy my experience; what marks of good nature my Sylvia has about her.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: My Captains! my Sons of Mars, and Imps of Venus! well encountred, what shall we have a sparkling Bottle or two, and use Fortune like a Jade? Beaugard you are a Rogue, you are a Dog, I hate you, get you gon, go.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But Sir Iolly, what news from Paradise Sir Iolly? Is there any hopes I shall come there too Night!

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: May be there is, may be there is not; I say let us have a Bottle, and I will say nothing else without a Bottle, after a Glass or two my Heart may open.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Why then we will have a Bottle Sir Iolly.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Will? we'l have dozens▪ and drink till we'r wise, and speak well of no body, till we are lewder than midnight-whores, and out-rail disbanded Officers.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Only one thing more my noble Knight, and then we are entirely at thy disposal.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Well and what's that? what's the business?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: This Friend of mine here stands in need of thy Assistance, he's damnably in Love Sir Iolly.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: In love is he so! in Love! 'ods my Life! is she! what's her Name? where does she live? I warrant you I know her, she's in my Table-Book I'l warrant you: Virgin, Wise, or Widdow!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: In troth Sir Iolly, that's something a difficult question, but as Virgins go now, she may pass for one of them.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Virgin very good: let me see; Virgin: Virgin, Virgin, oh here are the Virgins, truly I meet with the sewest of this sort of any, well and the first Letter of her Name now! for a wager I guess her.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Then you must know Sir Iolly, that I love my Love with an S.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: S. S. S. Oh here are the Esses, let me consider now— Sappho.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: No sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Selinda.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Neither.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Sophronia.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You must guess again I assure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Silvia.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, Sir Iolly, that's the fatal Name, Silvia the fair, the witty, the ill-natured, do you know her my Friend?

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Know her? Why she is my Daughter, and I have adopted her these seven years: Silvia, let me look; Light Brown Hair, her Face Oval and Roman, quick sparkling Eyes, plump pregnant Ruby Lips, with a Mole on her Breast, and the perfect likeness of a Heart-Cherry on her left Knee; Ah Villain! Ah sly Cap! have I caught you; are you there i'faith? well and what says she? is she coming? do her Eyes betray her? does her Heart beat, and her Bubbies rise, when you talk to her, hah?—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Look you sir Iolly, all things considered, it may make a shift to come to a Marriage in time.—

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: I'l have nothing to do in it, I won't be seen in the business of Matrimony; make me a Match-maker? a filthy Marriage Broker, Sir I scorn, I know better things; look you Friend, to carry her a Letter from you or so, upon good Terms, though it be in a Church I'l deliver it, or when the business is come to an issue, if I may bring you handsomely together, and so forth; I'l serve thee with all my Soul; and thank thee into the bargain: thank thee heartily dear Rogue, I will you little Cock-sparrow, faith and troth I will; but no Matrimony Friend, I'l have nothing to do with Matrimony; 'tis damn'd invention worse than a Monopoly, and a destroyer of civil correspondence.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Gentlemen your room is ready, your Wine and Ice upon the Table, will your Honours please to walk in?

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Ay wine, wine, give us wine, a pox on Matrimony, Matrimony in the Devils name.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: But if an honest Harlot or two chance to enquire for us Friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: Right Sirrah, if Whores come never so many, give 'em reverence, and reception, but nothing else, let nothing but Whores and Bottles come near us, as you tender your Ears.

div.stage: [they go within the Scene where is discover'd Table and Bottles.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why there's, there's the land of Canaan now in little, hark you, Drawer, Dog, shut, shut the Door Syrrah, do you hear, shut it so close, that neither cares, nor necessitys may peep in upon us.

div.stage: [Enter Sir Davy, Fourbin and Bloody Bones, Drawer.]

sp.speaker: Fourbin.
sp.p: Bloody-bones be you sure to behave your self handsomely and like your profession, shew your self a Cut-Throat of parts, and wee'l fleece him.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: My Lady says, We must be expeditious, Sir Iolly has giv'n notice to the Capt. by this time, so that nothing is wanting but the management of this oven-grown Gull to make us Hectors at large, and keep the Whore Fortune under.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Welcome Gentlemen, very welcome Sir, wil't please you to walk into a Room? or shall I wait upon your Honours pleasure here.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Sweet heart let us be private, and bring us Wine hither, so— [sits down. From this moment, War, war; and mortal dudgeon against that enemy of my Honour, and Theif of my good Name called Beaugard. you can cut a Throat upon occasion you say Freind.

sp.speaker: Fourbin.
sp.p: Sir cutting of Throats is my Hereditary vocation, my Father was hang'd for cutting of Throats before me, and my Mother for cutting of Purses.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: No▪ more to be said, my Courage is mounted like a little French-man upon a great Horse; and I'l have him murder'd.

sp.speaker: Fourbin.
sp.p: Sir, Murder'd you say Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ay Murder'd I say Sir, his Face slay'd off, and nayl'd to a post in my great Hall in the Countrey, amongst all the other Trophies of wild Beasts slain by our Family since the Conquest: there's never a Whore-Masters head there yet.

sp.speaker: Fourbin.
sp.p: Sir for that let me recommend this worthy Friend of mine to your Service, he's an industrious Gentleman and one that will deserve your Favour.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: He looks but somthing ruggedly though methinks.

sp.speaker: Fourbin.
sp.p: But Sir his Parts will attone for his Person: forms and fashions are the least of his study: he affects a sort of Phylosophical negligence indeed, but Sir make trial of him, and you'l find him a Person fit for the work of this World.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: What trade are you Freind?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: No trade at all Freind, I profess Murder: Rascally Butchers make a trade on't, tis a Gentlemans Divertisement.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Do you profess Murder.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Yes sir, 'tis my Livelyhood: I keep a Wife and six Children by it.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Then Sir here's to you withal my Heart; wou'd I had done with these Fellows.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Well Sir if you have any Service for us; I desire we may receive your Gold and your instructions so soon as is possible.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Soft and fair Sweetheart, I love to see a little how I lay out my Money: have you very good trading now a days in your way Freind?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: In peaceable times a man may eat and drink comfortably upon't, a private Murder done handsomely is worth Money: but now that the Nation's unsettled there are so many general undertakers▪ that 'tis grown almost a Monopoly, you may have a man Murder'd almost for little or nothing and no Lady e'r know who did it neither.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Pray what Country man are you? where were you born most Noble Sir?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Indeed my Country is Forreign, I was Born in Argier; my Mother was an Apostate Greek my Father a Ranegado English Man, who by oppressing of Chistian Slaves grew Rich; for which when he lay sick, I Murder'd him one day in his Bed: made my escape to Maltha, where imbracing the Faith I had the Honour given me to command a thousand Horse aboard the Gallies of that State.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Oh Lord Sir! my humble Service to you again.

sp.speaker: Fourbin.
sp.p: He tells you Sir but the naked Truth.

sp.speaker: Sir Iolly.
sp.p: I doubt it not in the least most worthy Sir: these are devilish Fellows I'l warrant 'em

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: War Friend, and shining Honour has bin our Province, till rusty peace▪ reduced us to this base obscurity, Ah Bloody Bones! Ah when thou and I commanded that party as the Seige of Philipsburgh! where in the Face of the Army wee took the impenetrable half Moon.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Half Moon Sir! by your Favour 'twas a whole Moon.

sp.speaker: Fourbin.
sp.p: Brother thou art in the right, 'twas a full Moon, and such a Moon Sir!—

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: I doubt it not in the least Gentlemen, but in the mean-while to our business.

sp.speaker: Fourbin.
sp.p: With all my Heart so soon as you please.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Do you know this Beaugard, he's a devlish fellow I can tell you but that, he's a Captain.

sp.speaker: Fourbin.
sp.p: Has he a Heart think you Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Oh like a Lion! he fears neither God, Man, nor Devil.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: I'l bring it you for your Breakfast to Morrow, did you never eat a Mans Heart Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Eat a Mans Heart Friend!

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Ah, Ay, a Mans Heart Sir, it makes absolutely the best Raggoust in the World: I have eaten forty of 'em in my time without Bread.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh Lord! a Mans Heart! my humble service to you Both Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Why your Algerine Pirates eat nothing else at sea, they have them always potted up like Venison, your well-grown Dutchmans Heart makes an excellent Dish with Oyl and Pepper.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh Lord! oh Lord! Friend, Friend, a word with you: how much must you and your Companion have to do this business?

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: What and bring you the Heart home to your house?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: No, no, keeping the Heart for your own eating, I'l be rid of 'em as soon as possible I can.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: You say Sir he's a Gentleman?—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Ay such a sort of Gentleman as are about this Town: the Fellow has a pretty handsome outside, but I believe little or no money in his Pockets.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Therefore we are like to have the honour to receive the more from your Worships bounty.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: For my part I care for no mans bounty: I expect to have my bargain perform'ed, and I'l make as good a one as I can.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Look you Friend,: don't you be angry Friend, don't be angry Friend before you have occasion: you say you'l have— let's see how much will you have now— I warrant the Devil and all by your good will.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Truely Sir David if as you say, the Man must be well murder'd without any remorse or mercy, betwixt Turk and Jew it is honestly worth two hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Two hundred pounds! Why I'l have a Physitian shall kill a whole Family for half the money.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Damme Sir, how do yemean?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Damme Sir how do I mean? Damme Sir not to part with my mony.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Not part Brother!

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Brother the Wight is improveable, and this must not be born withal.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Have I for this dissolu'd Circean Charms? broke Iron durance: whilst from these firm Legs the well fil'd useless Fetters dropt away, and left me Master of my native freedom.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What, what does he mean now?

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Truely Sir I am sorry to see it with all my heart, 'tis a distraction that frequently seizes him, though I am sorry it should happen so unluckily at this time.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Distracted say you! is he so apt to be distracted?

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Oh Sir rageing mad: we that live by Murder are all so: Guilt will never let us sleep. I beseech you Sir stand clear of him, he's apt to be very mischievous at these unfortunate hours.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Have I been drunk with tender Infants blood? and ript up teeming Wombs? Have these bold hands ransackt the Temples of the Gods, and stab'd the Priests before their Altars? Have I done this? hah!

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: No Sir, not that I know Sir, I would not say any such thing for all the World Sir, worthy Gentleman, I beseech you Sir, you seem to be a civil person: I beseech you Sir to mitigate his passion, I'l do any thing in the World, you shall command my whole Estate.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Nay after all Sir, if you have not a ming to have him quite murder'd, if a swinging drubbing to bed-rid him or, so, will serve your turn, you may have it at a cheaper rate a great deal.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Truly Sir, with all my heart, for methinks now I consider matters better, I would not by any means be guilty of another mans blood.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Why then let me consider— to have him beaten substantially, a beating that will stick by him, will cost you— half the money.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What one hundred pounds! Sure the Devil's in you, or you would not be so unconscionable.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: The Devil! where? where is the Devil? shew me; I'l tell thee Belzebub thou hast broke thy Covenant, didst thou not promise me eternal plenty, when I resign'd my Soul to thy allurements '

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Ah Lord!

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Touch me not yet: I've yet ten thousand Murders to Act before I'm thine: with all those sins I'l come with full damnation to thy Caverns of endless pain and houl with thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Bless us! what will become of this mortal Body of mine? Where am I? Is this a house? do I live? am I Flesh and Blood?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: There, there's the Feind again! don't chatter so, and grin at me, if thou must needs have prey, take here, take him, this Tempter that would bribe me with shining Gold, to stain my hands with new iniquity.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Stand off I charge thee Stain, wheresoe'r thou art, thou hast no right nor claim to me, I'l have thee bound in Necromantick Charms. Heark you Friend, has the Gentleman given Soul to the Devil?

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Only pawn'd it a little: that's all.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Let me beseech you Sir to dispatch, and get rid of him as soon as you can. I would gladly drink a Bottle with you Sir, but I hate the Devils Company mortally, as for the hundred pound here, here it is ready, no more words, I'l submit to your good nature and discretion.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Then Wretch take this and make thy peace with the infernal King, he loves Riches, sacrifice and be at rest.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: 'Tis done: I'l follow thee, lead on, nay if thou smile, I more defy thee▪ Eee, Fa, Fum.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: 'Tis very odd this.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Very odd indeed I'm glad he's gone though.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Now Sir, if you please we'l refresh our selves with a chearful glass, and so Chaque un chez lui— I would fain make the Gull drunk a little to put a little mettle into him▪

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: With all my heart Sir, but no more words of the Devil, if you love me.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: The Devil's an Ass Sir, and here's a Health to all those that defy the Devil

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: With all my heart, and all his works too.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Nay Sir, you must do me right I assure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Not so full, I not so full, that's too much of all Conscience: in 〈◊〉 Friend these are sad times, very sad times: but here's to you.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Pox o' the times, the times are well enough so long as a man has money in his Pocket.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: 'Tis true, here I have been bargaining with you about a Murder, but never consider that Idolatry is coming in full speed upon the Nation, pray what Religion are you of Friend?

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: What Religion am I of sir? Sir your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Truly a good Conscience is a great happiness; and so I'l pledg you, hemph, hemph, but shan't the Dog be Murdered this Night.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: My Brother Rogue is gon by this time to set him, and the business shall be done effectually I'l warrant you, here's rest his soul.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: With all my Heart Faith, I hate to be uncharitable.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Look you 'tis a very impudent thing not to be drunk by this time, shall Rogues stay in Taverns to sip Pints, and be Sober, when honest Gentlemen are drunk by Gallons, I'll have none on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Oh Lord, whose's there?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: I beseech your Honour, our house will be utterly ruin'd by this means.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Damne your house, your Wife and Children, and all your Family, you Dog!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, who are you.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Who am I Sir? what's that to you, Sir? will you tickle my Foot you Rouge!

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: I'll tickle your Guts you Paultroon presently.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Tickle my guts you Mad-Cap, I'll tickle your Toby if you do.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: What with that circumsis'd Band? That grave hypocrytital Beard of the reformation Cut? Old Fellow, I believe your a Rogue.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Sirrah you are a Whore, an errant Bitch-Whore, I'll use you like a Whore, I'll kiss you, you Jade, I'll Ravish you, you Buttuck, I am a Justice of the Peace, Sirrah, and that's worse.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: Dam you, Sir, I care not if you were a Constable and all his Watch; what, such a Rogue as you send honest Fellows to prison, and countenance Whores in your Jurisdiction for bribery, you Mongrel, I'll beat you, Sirrah, I'll brain you, I'll murder you, you Moon-Calf.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, Sir, Constable, Watch, stokes, stokes, stokes, murder—

sp.speaker: Caur.
sp.p: Huzza, Beaugard!

sp.speaker: Four.
sp.p: Well, Sir, the busiuefs is done, we have bargain'd to Murder you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Murder'd! whose to be murder'd? ha, Fourbin!

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: You are to be murder'd, Friend, you shall be murder'd, Friend.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But how am I to be murder'd? Who's to murder me, I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Four.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, Fourbin, I am the man with your worships leave, Sir David, has given me this gold to do it handsomely.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir David! uncharitable Cur, what Murder an honest Fellow for being Civil to his Family? What can this mean Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: No 'tis for not being Civil to his Family, that it means Gentleman, therefore are you to be murder'd to Night, and buried a Bed with my Lady, you Jack Straw, you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I understand you Friends, the old Gentleman has design'd to have me butcher'd and you have kindly contriv'd to turn it to my advantage in the affair of Love, I am to be murder'd but as it were Gentlemen, hah!

sp.speaker: Four.
sp.p: Your Honour has a piercing Judgment: Sir, Captain Courtines gone.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: No matter let him go, he has a design to put in practice this Night too, and would perhaps but spoil ours; but when, Sir Iolly, is this business to be brought about.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Presently, 'tis more then time 'twere done already, go, get you gone I say▪ hold, hold, let's see your left Ear first, hum— ha— you are a Rogue, y'are a Rogue, get you gone, get you gone, go.

div.stage: Enter Sylvia and Maid in the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: But why Madam, will you use him so inhumanly? I'm confident he loves you.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Oh! a true Lover is to be found out like a true Saint, by the Trial of his patience; have you the Cords ready.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Here they are, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Letv 'em down, and be sure what it comes to Trial, to pull lustily; is Will. the Footman ready.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: At your Ladiships command, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: I wonder he should stay so long, the Clock has struck twelve.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: And was she not frank and free▪
And was she not kind to me.
To lock up her Cat in her Cupboard,
And give her key to me, to me:
To lock up her Cat in her Cupboard,
And give her key to me.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: This must be he: Ay 'tis he, and as I am a Virgin roaring drunk; but if I find not a way to make him sober—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Here, here's the Window: Ay, that's Hell-door, and my damnation's in the inside: Sylvia, Sylvia, Sylvia: Dear Imp of Satan appear to thy Servant.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Who calls on Sylvia in this dead of night, when rest is wanting to her longing eyes.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: 'Tis a poor wretch can hardly stand upright drunk with thy Love, and if he falls he lies.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Courtine, is't you?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes, Sweet-Heart 'tis I, art thou ready for me?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Fasten your self to that Cord there; there, there it is.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Cord! where? Oh, oh, here, here, so now to Heav'n in a string.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Have you done.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes, I have done Child, and wou'd sain be doing too Hussy.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Then pull away, hoa up, hoa up, hoa up, so avast there, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Are you very much in Love, Sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh damnably Child, damnably.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: I'm sorry for't with all my heart, good Night Captain.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Ha gone, what left in Erasinus Paradice between Heav'n and Hell? If the Constable should take me now for a stragling Monkey hung by the Loins, and hunt me with his cry of Watchmen! Ah Woman, Woman, Woman, well a merry Life, and a short, that's all.

div.l: God prosper long our Noble King,
Our Lives and Safeties all.
I am mighty loyal to Night.
div.stage: Enter Fourbin, and Bloody-bones as from Sir Davids House.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: Murder, Murder, Murder! help, help, Murder.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Nay, if there be murder stirring, 'tis high time to shift formy self.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: (Squeaking,) A h h h h!

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Yonder, yonder he comes murder, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: 'Tis very Late; but Murder is a melancholly business, and Night is fit for't, I'll go home.

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Whose there? open the door you Whelp of Babylon.

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: Oh Sir, y'are Welcome home; but here is the saddest news! here has been murder committed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue you Fool, and go to sleep, get you in do you hear, you talk of Murder you Rogue? you meddle with State-Affairs? Get you in.

div.stage: The Scene opens the middle of the House and discovers Sir Jolly and the Lady putting Beaugard in order as if he were dead.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Ly still, ly still you Knave, close, close when I bid you, you had best quest, and spoil the sport, you had!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But pray how long must I lye thus?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, you'll think the time mighty tedious.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sweet Creature, who can counterfeit Death when you are near him?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: You shall Sirrah, if a body desires you a little, so you shall, we shall spoil all else, all will be spoil'd else Man, if you do not: Stretch out longer, longer yet, as long as ever you can, so so, hold your breath, hold your breath, very well.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.p: Madam, here comes Sir David.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Odds so, now close again as I told you, close you Divel, now stir if you dare; stir but any part about you if you dare now; odd I hit you such a rap if you do, lye still, lye you still.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: My Dear, how dost thou do, my Dear? I am come.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Ah Sir! what is't y'ave done? Y'ave ruin'd me, your Family, your Fortune, all is ruin'd, where shall we go, or whither shall we flye?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Where shall we go, why we'll go to bed you little Jackadandy, why you are not a Wench you Rogue, you are a Box, a very Boy, and I love you the better for't, Sirrah hei!—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Ah Sir, see there.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Bless us, a man! and bloody! what upon my Hall Table!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Two Ruffians brought him in just now pronouncing the inhumane deed, was done by your command, Sir Iolly came in the distracting Minute, or sure I had dy'd with my distracting Fears, how could you think on a revenge so horrid?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: As I hope to be sav'd Neighbour I only bargain'd with 'em to Bastinado him in a way, or so, as one Friend might do another, but do you say that he is dead?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Dead, dead as Clay; stark stiff and useless all, nothing about him stirring, but all's cold and still, I knew him a lusty Fellow once, a very metteled Fellow, 'tis a thousand pitties.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: What shall I do? I'll throw my self upon him, kiss his wide wounds and weep till blind as Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Oh come not near him, there's such horrid Antipathy follows all murders, his wounds would stream afresh shou'd you but touch him.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p:
Dear Neighbour, Dearest Neighbour, Friend, Sir Iolly as you love Charity pity my wretched Case, and give me Counsell,
I'l give my Wife and all my Estate to have him live again, or shall I bury him in the Arbour at the upper end of the Garden.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Alas a day Neighbour, never think on't, never think on't, the dogs will find him there, as they scrape holes to bury bones in, there is but one way that I know of.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: What is it dear Neighbour, what is it? you see I am upon my knees to you, take all I have and ease me of my fears.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Truly the best thing that I can think of, is putting of him to bed, putting him into a warm bed, and try to fetch him to life again, a warm bed is the best thing in the World, my Lady may do much too, she's a good Woman, and as Iv'e been told, understands a green wound well.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: My dear, my dear, my dear!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Bear me away, oh send me hence far off, where my unhappy name may be a stranger; and this sad accident no more remember'd to my dishonour.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ah but my Love! my Joy! are there no bowels in thee.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Prithee do so much as try thy skill, there may be one drachm of life left in him yet, take him up to thy Chamber, put him into thy own bed, and try what thou canst do with him; prithee do, if thou canst but find motion in him, all may be well yet, I'l go up to my Closet in the Garret, and say my prayers in the mean while.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Will ye then leave this ruine on my hands.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Pray, pray my Dear, I beseech you Neighbour help to perswade her if it be possible.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Faith Madam do, try what you can do, I have a great fansie you may do him good: who can tell but you may have the gift of stroaking; pray Madam be perswaded.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I'l do what e'r's your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: That's my best Dea●: I'l go to my Closet and pray for thee heartily, Alas, alas, that ever this should happen—

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: So, is he gone, Madam my Angel!

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: What no thanks, no reward for old Iolly now? Come hither Hussie, you little Canary- bird, you little Hop o' my thumb come hither: make me a Court'sie, and give me a kiss now, hah! give me a kiss I say, odd I will have a kiss, so I will, I will have a kiss if I set on't; shoogh, shoogh, shoogh, get you into a corner when I bid you, shoogh, shoogh, shoogh, what there already? [She goes to Beaugard. Well, I ha' done, I ha' done, this 'tis to be an old Fellow now.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And will you save the life of him y'ave wounded?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Dare you trust your self to my skill for a cure?

div.stage: [Sir Davy appears at a Window above.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Hist! hist! close, close, I say again, yonder's Sir Davy, odds so!

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: My dear, my dear! my dear!—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Whos's that calls? my Love, is't you.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ah some comfort, or my heart's broke▪ is there any hopes yet? I've try'd to say my Prayers and cannot: if he be quite dead▪ I shall never pray again; Neighbour, no hopes?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Truly little or none, some small pulse I think there is left, very little, there's nothing to be done if you don't pray, get you to prayers, what ever you do, get you gone, nay don't stay now, shut the Window I tell you.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Well this is a great trouble to me, but good night.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Good night to you dear Neighbour. Get ye up [to Beaugard and Lady D.] get ye up and be gone into the next room, presently, make haste: but don't steal away till I come to you, be sure ye remember, don't ye stir till I come; Pish, none of this bowing and fooling, it but loses time, I'l only bolt the door that belongs to Sir Davy's Lodgings, that he may be safe, and he with you in a twinkle, Ah, h, h, h! so now for the door, very well, Friend you are fast.

div.l: Bonney Lass gan thou wert mine,
And twonty thoosand poonds aboot thee, &c.

div.head: ACT. V.
div.stage: Courtine bound on a Couch in Sylvia's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: HEigho! heigho! ha! where am I? was I drunk or no last night? something leaning that way. But where the Devil am I? sincerely in a Bawdy-House: Fogh! what a smell of sin is here! let me look about; if there be ever a Geneva Bible or a Practice of Piety in the room. I am sure I have guest right, what's the matter now! ty'd fast! bound too! what tricks have I play'd to come into this condition! I have lighted into the Territories of some merrily dispos'd Chamber maid or other, and she in a witty sit forsooth hath trust me up thus, has she pinn'd no rags to my tail, or chalkt me upon the back trow? would I had her Mistress here at a venture:

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: What would you do with her my enchanted Knight if you had her, you are too sober for her by this time, next time you get drunk you may perhaps venture to scale her Balcany like a valiant Captain as you are.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Hast thou done this my dear destruction ● and am I in thy limbo? I must confess when I am in my Beer, my Courage does 〈◊〉 away with me now and then: but let me loose and thou shalt see what a gentle humble Animal thou hast made me. Fie upon't, what tie me up like an ungovernable curr to the frame of a table, let, let thy poor dog loose that he may fawn and make much of thee a little.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: What with those Paws which you have been ferreting Moor-fields withal, and are very dirty still? after you have been daggling your self abroad for prey, and can meet with none, you come sneaking hither for a crust, do you?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Shall I fetch the Whip and the Bell, Madam? and flash him for his roguery soundly?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Indeed, indeed! do you long to be forking of man's flesh, Madam Flea-trap? does the Chaplain of the Family use you to the exercise, that you are so ready for it?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: If you should be let loose and taken into favour now; you would be for rambling again so soon as you had got your liberty?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Do but try me, and if ever I prove recreant more, let me be beaten and us'd like a dog in good earnest.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Promise to grant me but one request, and it shall be done

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Hear me but Swear.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: That any body may do ten thousand times a day.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Upon the word of a Gentleman, nay as I hope to get Mony in my Pocket.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: There I believe him l●lye, you'l keep your Word you say.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: If I don't, hang me up in that Wenches old Garters.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: See Sir, you have your freedom.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Well now name the price; what must I pay for't?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: You know Sir, considering our small acquaintance, you have been pleased to talk to me very freely of love matters.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: I must confess, I have been something to blame that way, but if ever thou hearest more of it from my mouth after this nights adventure, would I were well out of the House!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Have a care of swearing, I beseech you, for you must understand, that spight of my teeth, I am at last fallen in love most unmercifully.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: And dost thou imagine I am so hard-hearted a Villain as to have no compassion of thee.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: No, for I hope he's a man you can have no exceptions against.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Yes, yes, the man is a man, I'l assure you, that's one comfort

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Who do you think it may be now? try if you can guess him.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Whoever he is, he's an honest fellow I'l warrant him, and I believe will not think himself very unhappy neither.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: If a Fortune of 5000 pounds, pleasant nights, and quiet days can make him happy, I assure you he may be so, but try once to guess at him.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: But if I should be mistaken.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Why who is it you would wish me to?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: You have 5000 pound you say?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Faith Child to deal honestly I know well enough who tis I wish for, but Sweet-heart, before I tell you my inclinations, it were but reasonable that I knew yours.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Well Sir, because I am confident you will stand my friend in the business, I'l make a discovery, and to hold you in suspence no longer, you must know I have a months-mind to an Arm full of your dearly beloved friend and brother Captain, what say you to't?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Madam your humble Servant, good buy, that's all.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: What thus cruelly leave a Lady that so kindly took you in in your last nights pickle into her Lodging, whither would you rove now, my Wanderer?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Faith Madam, you have dealt so gallantly in trusting me with your passion, that I cannot stay here without telling you, that I am three times as much in love with an acquaintance of yours, as you can be with any friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Not with my waiting Woman I hope, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: No, but it is with a certain Kinswoman of thine Child, they call her my Lady Dunce, and I think this is her House too, they say she will be civil upon a good occasion, therefore prithee be charitable, and shew me the way to her Chamber a little.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: What commit Adultery Captain, fie upon't! What hazard your soul!

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: No, no, only venture my body a little, that's all; look you, you know the secret, and may imagine my desires, therefore as you would have me assist your inclinations, pray be civil and help me to mine, look you, no demurring upon the matter, no qualms, but shew me the way, or you Hussie, you shall do't, any Bawd will serve at present, for I will go.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: But you shan't go, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Shan't go, Lady?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: No, shan't go, Sir▪ did I not tell you when once you had got your liberty, that you would be rambling again.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Why Child, would'st thou be so uncharitable to tie up a poor Jade to an empty Rack in thy Stable, when he knows where to go elsewhere and get Provender enough.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Any musty Provender, I find, will serve your turn, so you have it but cheap, or at another mans charges.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: No Child, I had rather my Ox should graze in a Field of my own, than live hide-bound upon the Common, or run the hazzard of being Pounded every day for trespasser.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Truly all things consider'd, 'tis great pity so good a Husband man as you should want a Farm to cultivate.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Would'st thou be but kind, and let me have a bargain in a Tenement of thine, to try how it would agree with me.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: And would you be contented to take a Lease for your Life.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: So pretty a Lady of the Mannour and a moderate Rent.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Which you'l be sure to pay very punctually.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: If thou doubtest my honesty, faith e'en take a little earnest before hand.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Not so hasty neither, good Tenant; Imprimis, You shall oblige your self to a constant residence, and not by leaving the House uninhabited, let it run to repairs.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Item, For your own sake you shall promise to keep the Estate well 〈◊〉, and enclos'd least sometime or other your Neighbours Cattle break in and spoil the crop on the Ground Friend.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Very just and reasonable, provided I don't find it lie too much to Common already.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Item, You shall enter into strict Covenant, not to take any other Farm upon your hands, without my consent and approbation, or if you do, that then it shall be lawful for me to get me another Tenant, how and where I think sit.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Faith that's something hard though, let me tell you but that Landlady.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Upon these terms we'l draw Articles.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: And when shall we Sign 'em.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Why this morning as soon as the ten a Clock Office in Covent-garden is open.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: A bargain, but how will you answer your entertainment of a drunken Red-coat in your Lodgings at these unseasonable hours.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: That's a secret you will be hereafter obliged to keep for your own sake, and for the Family, your Friend Beaugard shall answer for us there.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Indeed I fancy'd the Rogue had mischief in his head, he behav'd himself so soberly last night, has he taken a Farm lately too.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: A trespasser, I believe, if the truth were known upon the Provender you would fain have been biting at just now.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam, Madam, have a care of your self; I see Lights in the great Hall, whatever is the matter, Sir Davy and all the Family are up.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: I hope they'l come and catch me here: Well, now you have brought me into this condition, what will you do with me, hah!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: You won't be contented for a while to be ty'd up like a Jade to an empty Rack without Hay, will you?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Faith e'en take me, and put my mark upon me quickly, that if I light into strange hands they may know me for a Sheep of thine.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: What by your wanting a Fleece do you mean? If it must be so come follow your Sheperdess B a a a.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: I cannot sleep, I shall never sleep again, I have pray'd too so long, that were I to be hang'd presently, I have never a prayer left to help my self, I was no sooner lay'n down upon the Bed just now, and faln into a slumber, but methought the Devil was carrying me down Ludgate-hill a Gallop, six puny Fiends with flaming Fire-forks running before him like Link boys, to throw me headlong into Fleet●●●ch, which seemed to be turned into a lake of Fire and Brimstone; would it were Morning.

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, it has been a very dismal night.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: But did'st thou meet never a white thing upon the stairs.

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: No, Sir, not I, but methoughts I saw our great Dog Touzer, with his brass Collar on, stand at the Cellar-door as I came along the old Entry.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: It cou'd never be, Touzer has a Chain, had this thing a Chain on?

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: No Sir, no Chain but it had Touzers eyes for all the World.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: What ugly great frightful eyes?

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, huge sauser eyes, but mightily like Touzers.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Oh Lord! oh Lord! heark! heark!

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: What! what I beseech you Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: What's that upon the stairs? didst thou hear nothing? hist, heark, pat, pat, pat, heark, heih!

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: Hear nothing! where Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Look! look! what's that! what's that! in the corner there?

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: There.

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: What upon the Iron Ghost?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: No, the long black thing up by the old Clock-case, see! see! now it stirs, and is coming this way.

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, speak to it, you are a Justice 'o peace, I beseech you, I dare not stay in the House: I'l call the Watch and tell 'em Hell's broke loose, what shall I do? oh!

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Oh Vermin, if thou art a true Servant have pity on thy Master, and do not forsake me in this distressed condition, Satan be gone, I defie thee, I'l repent and be sav'd, I'l say my prayers, I'l go to Church; help! help! help! was there any thing, or no, in what hole shall I hide my self.

div.stage: Enter Sir Jolly, Fourbin and Bloody-bones.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: That shou'd be Sir Davy's voice, the waiting Woman indeed told me he was afraid and could not sleep, pretty Fellows, pretty Fellows both y'ave done your business handsomly, what I'l warrant you have been a Whoring together now hah! You do well, you do dwell, I like you the better for't, what's a Clock?

sp.speaker: Four.
sp.p: Near four, Sir, 'twill not be day yet these two hours.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Very well, but how got ye into the House?

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: A ragged retainer of the Family, Vermin I think they call him, let us in as Physitians sent for by your Order.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Excellent Rogues! and then I hope all things are ready as I gave Directions.

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p: To a tittle, Sir, there shall not be a more critical Observer of your Worships pleasure than your humble Servant the Chevalier Fourbin.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Get you gone you Rogue, You have a sharp Nose, and are a nimble Fellow; I have no more to say to you, stand aside▪ and be ready when I call, here he comes, hist, hem, hem, hem.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Hah! what art thou? approach thou like the rugged Bank-side Bear, the Eastcheap-bull, or Monster shewn in Fair, take any shape but that, and I'l confront thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Alas unhappy Man! I am thy Friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Thou caust not be my Friend for I defy thee, Sir Iolly! Neighbour! hah! is it you? are you sure it is you, are you? Your self? if you be give me your hand, Alas a day I ha' seen the Devil.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: The Devil Neighbour!

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, there's no help for't, at first I fancy'd it was a young white Bears Cub danceing in the shadow of my Candle, then ● was turn'd to a pair of blew Breaches with wooden leggs on, stampt about the room as if all the Cripples in Town had kept their Rendezvouze there, when all of a sudden it appeard like a leathern Serpent, and with a dreadful clap of Thunder flew out of the Window.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Thunder! Why I heard no Thunder.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: That may be too, what were you asleep?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: A sleep quotha, no, no, no sleeping this Night for me I assure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Well what's the best news then? How does the Man?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: E'en as he did before he was born, nothing at all, he's Dead.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Dead! what quite dead!

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: As good as dead, if not quite dead, 'twas a horrid Murder, and then the terrour of Conscience, Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: And truly I have a very terrifi'd one, Friend, though I never found I had any Conscience at all till now, pray where about was his death's wound?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Just here, just under his left Pap, a dreadful gash.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: So very wide!

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Oh, as wide as my Hat, you might have seen his Lungs, Liver and Heart, as perfectly, as if you had been in his Belly.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Is there no way to have him privately Buried and conceal this Murder, must I needs be hang'd by the neck like a Dog, Neighbour; do I look as if I would be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Truly, Sir Davy, I must deal faithfully with you, you do look a little suspitiously at present; but have you seen the Devil, say you?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ay surely, it was the Devil, nothing else could have frighted me so.

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Bless us and guard us all the Angels, what's that?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Potestati sempiternaec ujus benevolentiâ servantur gentes, & cujus misericordia.

div.stage: Kneels, holding up his hands and mut'ring as if he pray'd

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Neighbour, where are you, Friend, Sir Davy.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ah, what ever you do, be sure to stand close to me, where, where is it?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Just, just there, in the shape of a Coach and six Horses against the wall.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Deliver us all, he won't carry me away in that Coach and six will he?

sp.speaker: Sir Iol.
sp.p: Do you see it?

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: See it! plain, plain, dear Friend advise me what I shall do? Sir Iolly, Sir Iolly, do you hear nothing? Sir Iolly, Hah! has he left me alone! Vermin.

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Am I alive? dost thou know me again? Am I thy Quondam Master, Sir Davy Dunce?

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: I hope I shall never forget you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Didst thou see nothing?

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, methought the House was all o' fire as it were.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Did'st thou not see how the Devils grinn'd and gnasht their teeth at me Vermin?

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, I was afraid one of 'em would have bit off my Nose, as he vanisht out of the door.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Lead me away, I'l go to my Wise, I'l die by my own dear Wife; run away to the Temple and call Councellor my Lawyer, I'l make over my Estate presently, I shan't live till noon, I'l give all I have to my Wife, Hah Vermin!

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, she's a very good Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ah much, much too good for me Vermin, thou can'st not imagine what she has done for me Man, she would break her heart if I should give any thing away from her, she loves me so dearly: Yet if I do die, thou shalt have all my old Shoes.

sp.speaker: Verm.
sp.p: I hope to see you live Many a fair day yet though.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.p: Ah, my Wife, my poor Wife, lead me to my poor Wife.

div.stage: Scene draws and discovers Sir Jolly, Beaugard, and Lady in her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: What think you now of a cold wet March over the Mountains, Your men tir'd, your Baggage not come up, but at night a dirty watry Plain to Encamp upon, and nothing to shelter you, but an old Leager Cloak as tatter'd as your Colours? is not this much better now than lying wet and getting the Sciatica?

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: The hopes of this made all Fatigue easie to me, the thoughts of Clarinda have a thousand times 〈…〉 me in my solitude, when e're I Marcht, I fancy'd still it was to my Clarinda! when I fought, I imagin'd it was for my Clarinda! but when I came home, and found Clarinda lost!— how could you think of wasting but a night in the rank surfeiting arms of this foul feeding Monster? this rotten trunck of a Man▪ that lays claim to you.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: The perswasion of Friends and the Authority of Parents!

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: And had you no more Grace, than to be rul'd by a Father and Mother?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: When you were gone, that should have given me better Counsel, how could I help my self?

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Methinks then you might have found out some cleanlier shift to have thrown away your self upon, than nauseous old age and unwholsome deformity.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: What upon some overgrown full fed Country Fool, with a Horse Face, a great ugly Head, and a great fine Estate, one that should have been drain'd and squeez'd, and jolted up and down the Town in 〈◊〉 with Cheats and Hectors, and so sent home at three o' Clock every Morning like a lolling Booby stinking, with a belly full of s●●mm'd Wine, and nothing in's Pockets.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: You might have made a tractable Beast of such a one, he would have been young enough for Training.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
